Authenticity vs Virtualization


To quote someone: "It's about how the different mediums interact with light. In a strip of analog film, you have crystals of silver salts, none of them are identical, every single crystal has a different size and orientation and every frame has a different arrangement. Of course they have to be kept within a certain size range (this is partially what determines the ISO value) - this is what makes it look more "natural" and pleasing to the eyes (in my opinion, to my eyes). Even if you film a 30 second clip of a completely static subject where nothing moves, every frame is still unique. A digital sensor has all the same sized pixels arranged neatly in rows and columns. If you did the same thing with a digital camera, you wouldn't be able to tell if you were looking at full-motion video or a still photograph. This is why movies shot on digital cameras look so bland and ... "creamy" is a good way to put it. The way they capture extreme value ranges is also different, meaning the darkest darks and the brightest lights."

To my mind it's like describing the difference between anbidealized, but sterile mathematical structure, and an actual living organism.

While it's true many professionals used to go out with large-capacity loaders and motor drives, taking hundreds of shots, most amateurs would go out with a roll of 12, 24 or 36, and have to make each shot count. So one of the reasons people say film "feels" different is certainly you must have a different attitude every time you push the button. I have done many large-format assignments where I had only ONE chance to get it right. One shot.
People who enjoyed this video might also enjoy the book "Making Kodak Film," by Robert Shanebrook. Shanebrook was an engineer and photographer, working at Eastman Kodak for 36 years. His book is not only technically accurate, but just loaded with picrures of all the raw materials (bales of cotton, for cellulose, pallets of silver ingots) and all the mavhines used in manufacture. One of the really interesting things to be learned is that Kodak actually employed many blind people, who rather than being handicapped turned out to be super-skilled, operating, adjusting and repairing conplex and potentially dangerous machinery in total darkness!

It's kind of funny to watch all of these young people gushing over film photography. I started in 35 mm photography in 1990 (I used a 110 camera before that). Back then, you took your film to a lab and had prints back in a day or 2. Then Walmart and drug stores started doing processing in-store in 1 hour. Good stuff! The printing was all analog: shining light through the negatives on to photo sensitive paper, which went through the machine in a continuous strip, tracking into each chemical tank, with the paper speed set to be in the bath for the correct time. It came out on the back side dry, in about 10 minutes, and was cut into 4x6 prints. The printer (machine operator) color corrected each image visually looking at the negative. The corrections were printed on the back of the print, and if they were off, the printer would reprint with better corrections. It was an art in itself.

Then the Fuji Frontier came out, and it was revolutionary. The machine scanned the roll, and the printer could color correct on a positive image. Much more accurate and faster than correcting from the negative view. Once the roll was corrected, the computer exposed the photographic paper using red, green, and blue lasers, then it was processed through the machine the same was as above. My friend owned a photo lab and had 2 Fuji Frontier machines. He said that Fuji was the first to develop the blue laser that made the laser exposure possible, so no other companies could use that technology. Indie lab uses just the scanner portion of the whole Fuji Frontier machine. The prints that came out of those machines were phenomenal. I've always loved Fuji's colors, especially the vivid blues and greens. Kodak colors were more muted. Through the 90's and early 2000's, I was a professional photographer shooting all sorts of events and weddings on film. I much prefer the images out of my Sony digital mirrorless camera, and the control that I have over the look of the final image, rather than handing off to another person. I have started digitizing my film images using my Sony camera, but have no desire to go back to film. I still have all of my old film cameras and lenses, 35mm and 120.

Film is natural way of capturing reality with its warmth.

When digital came in, I used to say, that digital shots are more perfect than it was in reality. And actually I know now why.

While film is a natural impression or catching of photons with their wavelengths, the digital cameras not just use transformations from photons to electric signals and assessment, but later to make a visible picture they use quite some programmed algorithm to work on contrast, brightness, gamma and so on.

All digital transformations make the image differ from reality. Like a built in photoshop, which makes images more perfect but less real.

Film is like having no question how to enhance an image to look better, as it is a real capture of an amount of photons without any postprocessing. What you see is what you get. Even with bad settings the amount of photons for each wavelength will be proportional, not changed. A piece of reality.

If you want to check out a digital analog (heh) to film. Check out Fujifilm X and G series cameras. The film simulations are actually pretty darn good. They most definitely are not film analogs. But ... that said. Fujifilm weekly releases really close simulations to film of specific types(Kodachrome 64, Kodak Porta 800, etc...). And comparing them side by side you'll find them difficult to tell apart when looking at scans and or compressed social media images. You get the grain and chrome effects you'd see in legitimate film.

Also

Get yourself one of the smallest memory cards you can for a digital camera, and start counting your shots. They are usually slow and only allow a relatively small amount of photos before needing processing or a card replacement. Buy them in bulk, use them like film rolls.

And still

You can adapt old manual style lenses to mirrorless cameras and get the slow purposeful / deliberate process of taking a photo. Again, you get that 'magic' from slow photography that way.

I’ve been trying to find the time to get my darkroom setup, but it’d be great to get back into color this way in the meantime.

I spent a lot of time in darkrooms in high school and college, and worked in a couple of photo labs in the ‘90s. We had Kodak and Fuji processors there that didn’t require a darkroom — film cassettes went in one end, cover closed, the film got pulled out into the machine and along a continuous path through developer, stop, fixer, wash, and dryer. Super easy, foolproof results.

I grew up shooting black and white film, and processing/printing it myself. My hands smelled like chemicals all the time. Part of me misses those days, and there’s nothing quite like the look of black and white film. I still have a developing tank somewhere, and I keep thinking I should get back into it, but it’s so hard to find the time at this point.

But that said, some of us who grew up shooting film never quite grew out of the habits that formed. Even when I shoot with my digital cameras, I’m selective about my shots. I don’t just hold down the shutter release; I compose and shoot a single photo, then compose and shoot the next, different photo. Old habits die hard.

What is the native resolution of 35mm color film vs the resolution of those pro scanners?  I got into film scanning in around 2002 for the purpose of generating Webpage content; really painful for home early adopters. The tools were primitive and it could take an hour per shot to get it to your needs. Apple's software was the best and Adobe Photoshop was a game changer. Oddly, for batch processing for the web (you often needed a consistent size and resolution with compression), Google's Picasa (now gone) was just fantastic.  Early Digital cameras were really disappointing. I had a Olympus that could store only 6-8 shots at high resolution. Flash memory was slow and low capacity. Addressing this one issue was what changed the world. Because there was a huge commodity market for "digital film" (flash SD cards) the price and capacity plummetted. This and cheap system on a chip processors allowed for MP3 players, higher resolution digital cameras, Internet of Things and many more evolutionary steps. All these things need deep storage and this one inflection point made that a reality.  It is funny, Kodak has contributed so much to ancillary markets. Chip fabrication is an ultra high resolution lithographic process. Kodak Research was involved in Cryptography.  I did not know they had a museum. That will be on my list. And as for film images - just look at Ansel Adam's work - absolutely moving.

I taught film based photography for 35 years and have an MFA degree in fine art photography. I also won many awards and have had features in all the top magazines.  No doubt there is nostalgia for film based photography.  I even have it from time to time. However, digital is better in evey way. One major drawback about film is you have to have your exposure right on the money or your image will never come out perfect because you cannot put back into the film the missing information.  With digital, it is there, even if you can't see it. You can tweak the image later and get it out! So, digital is much more forgiving.  Second, if you print your images in a darkroom and develop in chemicals, first you do not have nearly the control you have with digital software.  Second, you are breathing in chemicals that are not good for you.  The idea that a film based image has a different feel than a digital image is not true.  I cannot be more adamant about that.  If you want a "feel" there are countless ways to get it through digital means.  So, though I spent most of my life learning, doing, and teaching both black and white and color  film based photography, I will never go back. Digital is simply better, unless you are involved in some specialized type of photography.

I worked at Eastman Kodak in Rochester New York... I made the emulsion and also worked on the coating machines themselves , that worked like a sheet of emulsion  waterfalling on the plastic sheets as they were moved really fast under it ,very cool operation.i The gel which is the main ingredient , is crushed cow bones , fun fking factoid... different sizes from fingernail size to frosted flakes size. Food grade. Since we work 10-hour days, worked in these huge dark rooms all of the time except for lunches and breaks, we wouldn't see light for a full week in the winter time until we rotate to days, it was like living in Alaska 🤣🤣🤣 Hated Trick work.

I remember making digital photo's... Probably late '99.  But I get it. In audioworld we're certainly striving to have the same sound that was made by old technology, like tubes / valves, but also magnetic tape driven delays, even oil-can delay (that's a thing you should find out!)... All in digital plugin form, or guitarpedal. It is probably easier to get right than the slight blur that is inherent of film. In audio we call it saturation. That's what you hear on vinyl and tape: a bit of distortion, like blur.

I spent five years shooting, processing and printing analog imagery on a US Navy Aircraft carrier, then worked my way through college working in a color lab, processing thousands and thousands of rolls of film and prints, maintaining the machines, running test strips, the lot of it.  I guess you could say silver runs in my blood.  It is amazing and wonderful to see young people working to keep the science of photography alive.  Do understand, there is no magic.  It's very much applied science.  If the science is followed, the photo turns out every time, with the art left up to the eye of the photographer.  There was a reason an F-14 Tomcat with a TARPS pod could fly out and take perfectly exposed photos of a target every time.

I know this is an older video. I wish I had seen it when it first came out. I was on a road trip from Georgia to New Orleans via Wisconsin and the U.P. (ya hey!). I brought my digital Pentax SLR and a Kodak Retina IIIc from the 1950's. The digital camera was just for snapshots and video. It is quick and I get great results. The photography was done with the Kodak. Like Destin says in the video, it is a different thought process when you take film images. You look deeper into the subject, you look around the subject and spend more time framing the image. I still have my first camera given to me in 1964 by a photographer, Don Arndt. It is a Brownie Box camera. There are a couple of light leaks, but it still works. A little duct tape and it will be ready for another 60 years of photographs. The one thing I really love is working in the dark room. I never developed color film. But, the things you can bring out, the data that the film stores is amazing. My dad took a photo of a camp fire at night on a sandy beach with ISO 100 film. All you could see in the negative was the fire. But by burning in the background while shading the fire on the photographic paper you could suddenly see boats on the water 200 yards away. If you want to see the magic of a darkroom just check out any Ansel Adams photo.

There is something incredibly powerful about the fact that it is something that exists in one state and then is changed forever by the scene you expose it to. I remember looking at some photos in a war museum. They were taken during D-Day, and I remember realising that fact in the moment. That this material was right there at that time, being taken by a man who was probably terrified. It was incredibly emotional realising that this piece of paper was physically there in front of this terrible scene, capturing the photons that bounced back like lightning in a bottle. It's such a weird thing but it suddenly made everything feel so much more real and immediate. I love digital photography (I've made a successful career as a digital artist) but digital feels like an emulation or reconstruction, rather than a real reflection of what was.

I have to laugh... so this film is all about 'film' to use instead of a digital camera. 🤔 so where is the film to print? Ultimately you can simply use a digital camera and simulate digital film... save the cost of the film and the processing, and the chemical waste at the same time! I have been doing this for years - actually since the late 1990s. I used to shoot film back then and print direct from film and at the same time, produce a set of digital files. This was all done using Fuji Frontier processor/printer machinery. In the early 2000s I moved over to digital and simply simulated the 'look' (and grain) using Photoshop. Yes - this is INCLUDING the grain the mid-tones but less or none in the highlights and shadows. Many a fellow-professional has thought that I have used film stock to do this.
After all, as your film shows, all you are doing here is digitising film stock originals to a digital file anyway. Believe it or not this is actually what has been happening way back to the mid to early 1990s... it is just that you did not know this when you took your film in to a local/online develop & print shop. The latter simply billed you extra for the digital scan which they made as part of the process anyway! Prior to these sort of printing machines, photo prints were made direct from the film to the print and were not digitised at all.
I am intrigued how many who watched are mystified as to how the reference stickers are tallied to the job number... this was sort of shown out of sequence. For those who picked this up, they are stuck on the 'job-sheet' of the customer AND the film so that the two can be matched later after the film is process. What was not quite clear in your film is that the sticker for the film is stuck to the film BEFORE the Dip and Dunk processing - i.e. it goes through the chemistry along with the film and is never taken off. Sticking this ref. number onto the film is usually done in the light by retrieving the leader out of the film cassette. You will notice that, with the 120 film, these stickers were temporarily stuck onto the film spindles. This was done as you cannot retrieve the film leader from 120 film (as there isn't one!) in the light and therefore this has to be done in the dark once the film is removed from the role.
Great film btw... it has brought back many 'dark'(room) and latent memories.
Asante sana...

I worked at a 24 hour photo lab in Walgreens for a few years. I have to say,  the specific Walgreens I worked at wasn't in the best part of town, and the film the people brought in to be processed reflected the surrounding area in an honest, and often unsettling way... I could always tell it was a "John" dropping of his film because he'd smile and say something like,  " Make a couple prints for yourself"  The negatives would spit out the machine and I would scan them in to reveal blurry, unfocused images of pink and grey tones, sometimes a clump of hair was visible, but I understood what they were attempting to memorialize. Their late night ( sometimes midday) rendezvous, shot "from the hip"  with the local prostitutes. printed on glossy 4x5 paper for their scrapbooks or inspiration boards...but who am I to judge. I was just there to process the film from the cheap disposable camera.  People would also surprise me with photos of their dead relatives laying like plastic in the open casket. Makes sense why they would take pictures of that, just unexpected. Some of those pictures are burned into my mind like the burned silver exposed to light on film. Imagine if the dude at Walgreens were to print all the pictures on your iPhone photo library...different times. it's easier to hide now for better or worse I don't know. Anyways, film is fun. I miss the red glow of the darkrooms safe light and the caustic smell of developer.

Destin, you're missing half of the film/photo analog process. You put your images on film, then digitize the negative image and go digital from there. I grew up in a photo dark room before there was even color film. We (my dad and I) took pictures them processed the film, and used the film to expose photo paper then processed the paper just as we did the film. The result was a picture that had to be right from start to finish. You couldn't manipulate the image as you can in Photoshop. During the process you can change only the exposure of the film by setting the camera lense, and you could adjust the exposure of the paper, and that is all. You had to be much more skillful a photographer than you need to be today because you couldn't fix errors in Photoshop. When color film and paper came along the lab processes became much more complicated, and the skill of the photographer had to be much higher. In my day a photographer did much more than just snap pictures to be manipulated in Photoshop. Go back and look at the spectacular sharpness of well made color photos. Find some good ones and you will be blown away by the images done the "old fashioned" way.

A few things I was surprised didn't get mentioned...
1) The economics of film cameras. Back in the day, especially as a teen, I was keenly aware that every time I snapped the shutter I was spending about $1 ($0.50 for the film and another $0.50 for the processing and print). It made the photo all the more precious.
2) There were a few years there, where consumer film developing would include the option of prints AND digital copies. I hope I'm remembering correctly that the digital copy could be emailed, or received on a floppy disk (I don't think they were on CD). I don't remember the resolution being terribly high though, so not to the full capability of the digital printers, even of the day.
3) You don't have to trace back too much before those digital printers, to the days when the prints had to be exposed and developed onto photographic paper, much the way the photo negative was. I did quite a bit of this, with b&w photography in HS. We would go into the dark room, develop the film in a black plastic can (with a spiraling holder, that you rotated to 'agitate' the film in the chemicals. Then, you would load the film into a 'reverse' camera, which put a light behind the film, magnifying it on to a platform which, after focusing, you would turn the light off, load a piece of photographic paper and do an exposure. Then, into the baths, to develop the positive image. There were a surprising number of representations of this process, in 70's and 80's television and movies (likely due to the value as metaphor).

Pentax DSLR have the same experience. They purposely slow the shot speed to be more in the feeling of photography. Great platform to learn the process of learning on being photographer while not breaking the bank.

Film developing at home can have environmental impact as well as lead issues in your home. Study before developing or making a darkroom for prints.

Home with well water and septic system:

Ph levels in developer and stop bath can change your ph levels in your well water. The acidic levels in stop bath can actually lower a ph in your well and affect the water that goes into your well, over time.

This can lead to low ph on your home, which will damage and erode copper piping and lead to leaks in the house, and a rusted water heater. Eroding pipes can put metals in your drinking water, not safe.

Septic systems themselves can also be damaged with film developing and darkroom printing . Most film companies advise against processing at home with a septic system.

The running of water for long period for rinsing film and especially fiber prints can over flood your septic and cause major issues with your leaching fields and ecosystem of your septic tank.

The chemistry itself can also kill enzymes in your system and cause septic back up and even tank damage.


Please study the risks before processing and printing at home.

Interesting video. I started my photography in film almost 30 years ago and loved it. My family loved it because I was the only one who really documented all our special occasions on film. Even now and then I bring out the heavy photo albums and we reminisce. In 2005 I switched to digital. The convenience is very nice. No film or processing to buy unless you want to print. And being a stickler for color I can easily manipulate the pics to my liking and not have to tell the lab to redo them. It's also easier to show pictures from a computer or phone. That makes them easy to transport around the country or email them when I want to show distance relatives. I have lost some of the enthusiasm for photography since everyone takes pictures now with their phones and the uniqueness of it is gone.

However, with film it was exciting waiting for your prints, to see how well you shot your photos. Then you got to experience your vacation again. Lastly, when you found a great lab who knew exactly how you wanted your prints processed, that was icing on the cake.

I think the different feeling of film also has to do with the fact that there is no aliasing effect that you have in CCD/CMOS image sensors due to the regular alignment in an array. A digital image is discretized, an analog image is continuous. Also, chromatic aberration is probably less of an issue in film. I think these effects combined make a subtle difference to all edges and fine detail.

This video was such a pleasure. I am from Denmark, and the first job I had after I started living on my own back in 2008 was developing analog film. 35mm, 120mm, APS film. Although I never worked with the same development system, I am familiar with all the processes that we see in this video and worked with the same scanners. So nostalgic to watch. Film truly has a quality that digital photography still cannot match. But I think the systems need a significant redesign. Analog photography requires a lot more technical understanding than using a digital camera, if you want to have control over the end product. So in order for it to be competitive, it needs to become more user friendly. I also think that a higher format than 35mm would be preferable to most. I get the feeling that people who still wanna use film would also like to be able to do large prints. If it's just for digital use 35mm should be fine.
Anyway. Thank you for making this video. So much fun to watch.

I'm an xray tech in Rochester, NY.  Always running into retired Kodak professionals asking me about the modern equipment.  I liked to praise the methods the industry took at the time to search for solutions in chemistry, to make a product better or cheaper having teams of people doing chemistry experiments non-stop, one of which was my granddad.  Some of the processes at the time and many still were not understood by physics or science all around, but they went with it if it worked.  Healthcare is unfortunately not as pragmatic.  We can't test on people like we can chemicals and yet, the scientific method is so heavily leaned on which puts huge roadblocks on complex medicines. We often will ignore solutions if they are not fully understood which seems kind of dumb to me.

Up until recently film has had a certain edge over digital because a negative can hold a lot more detail in terms of colour and exposure than the likes of an 8 bit jpeg image from digital camera. However with technology advancing in the digital world and cameras worth only a few thousand dollars can now capture digital raw images in 16 bit at hundreds of frames per second - film making a comeback is nothing more than a fad for those looking for their dose of nostalgia. People entering the industry have no interest in film simply because of the costs associated with developing the film and the time it takes to review your photos/footage.
Film will die with the likes of Tarantino. Like black & white TV, it will become redundant. Apart from making the film larger, it's already reached its technological ceiling. Digital is only just in its infancy and it's getting better every day. Soon enough it'll just reach a point where digital is so clearly the winner that using film will be something you do because you want to, not because you need to.

14:20. It is not a chemistry game. Chemistry stays exactly the same, whenever possible on a Refrema processor. The flags on the rack dictate the TIME the film remains IN the chemistry. More time/less time equals a push/pull decision by the photographer -- effectivly exposure compensation. If you detiermine the lab is consistent, request "NORMAL processing" and no PUSH or PULL. Only push or pull if you think you under or over exposed the film. How do you determine this decision? Request a clip test. They literally cut the tail end of your roll off, process it, and let you see it. Then you decide how to process the rest. Unbelievable in the digital age. Props to you if this matters. -MP
32:38 It's called "delayed gratification." It's the way the world used to work. Keen, isn't it?

It was difficult for me to watch this. I started shooting photographs and developing my own film at school and then at my darkroom at home in 1978. I ended up getting a BFA at the Minneapolis College of Art and Design in Photography. I agree that you have to be much more thoughtful about shooting when you are limited to a roll of film. The magic you miss here is the art of printing. Processing film is just that, processing. I also worked my way through college developing thousands of rolls of film.

The magic is being in the dark room, exposing the paper to the light of the negative, and slowly watching it transform in front of you. You had to adjust the selective lightness and darkness by dodging. That meant cutting a piece of cardboard in the shape you want and jiggling it over the paper while it was exposed to lighten or darken the image. Color correction was done with thin plastic filters that you layered into the enlarger. If you want to focus on magic, skip this digital stuff and show the magic of printing.

One way I can compare the process you showed here would be taking the time to record music on tape, make a vinyl record of it, transfer that to a digital file, alter it digitally, and then releasing it digitally. Does that make sense? I would recommend your next video be about the magic of manual printing.

Two things:
1)
00:04:01 It confused me at first when you described the silver/developer interaction as the silver halide crystals becoming "actual silver metal." I was even momentarily tempted to offer a correction, before going down a bit of a research rabbit hole and learning more about the chemistry involved with latent image formation & final image development, and the difference between SILVER and SILVER HALIDE. It's FASCINATING!!
Thank you, not just for this super-fun video generally, but particularly for nudging me to dig in and develop (sorry) a better understanding of how the process I've used for 30+ years *actually works*!

2)
- Regarding the hard-to-explain (would you say intangible?) quality that you & so many of us love about looking at photos made on film...
I do believe that most of the reasons images shot on film have a certain "feel" FOR VIEWERS can be attributed to sometimes-subtle but pretty much always visually quantifiable characteristics of photographic film[s]. With an understanding of those characteristics (chiefly: grain, color & tonal limitations of various films), I believe one CAN digitally replicate the look (and "feel") of an image shot on film effectively enough that - without a great deal of difficulty - one could stump almost anybody over whether a given image was *originally captured on film*. (Forensic photo analysts would still be able to peg the digital artifacts of the replication in mere moments, of course.)

- Regarding the experience of SHOOTING on film, however... Well, as you suggest, and as anyone who has ever made photographs on film can attest, virtually NONE of the intangibles affiliated with shooting on film can be replicated digitally. Physical interaction with the film, chemistry, darkroom, etc; and the psychological impact of the whole experience, like working with a limited number of available exposures, knowing that your images are being physically written to your film by light when you make an exposure... even the nostalgia factor that is inescapably linked to shooting film in the digital age (and so much more).... there is just NO WAY to replicate all of THAT [magical?] stuff.

I really like your videos and your enthusiasm but I had your same reaction to digital photography, when I first tried it in 2003. I believe, as another person stated, you are feeling more of a nostalgic feel for film versus a true quality comparison. I grew up using film but completely fell in love with digital photography; I felt that it captured a more true to life image.
My first experience with digital was when I borrowed my brother in laws 4 megapixel Kodak Easyshare, while on vacation in San Diego. I took a couple hundred photos during the two weeks out there and barely any with my Canon AE1 film camera. I was impressed with not having to continually load another roll of film, as well as the quality of the "Auto exposure and digital processor"... Not to mention the digital telephoto, and the on demand video, without having to switch to a "Camcorder".
Look, if you are a really good photographer, you will have no problems with film but if you are an average photographer, film is more of a struggle than a joy. You'll shoot hundreds of rolls of film and only yield minimal results as far as truly "good/great pictures. Additionally, it is a complete disappointment when you get your photos back and realize that you had the settings/exposure set wrong, and all of your memories are lost, only to be remembered in your minds eye... Which fades over time. Where as in a digital world, you see the photo instantly and can retake it, if it's not to your liking.
What you may be referring to as a "quality" difference might be the comparison of any image taken with a "smart" phone versus one taken with a good quality 35mm digital camera... There is a Night & Day difference between the two. You will never get the same quality picture on a "smart" phone versus a 35mm digital camera, the image sensor is too small in the phone.
Again, great videos and enthusiasm but film has passed for a reason, the same reason anything that has gone the analog-to-digital route has passed.
One last thing, I was wondering why they were not using a "Darkroom Light "in their darkroom. Usually a normal light bulb is enclosed inside/behind a red or green filter of some type. In radiology, several years ago, when we still processed the film manually, by machine, the darkrooms used a "Wratten 6B Filter"-red in color. It did not harm/expose the silver halide crystals on X-ray film. These lights were bright enough to see everything, once your eyes adjusted... usually several seconds to a minute.
Also, any good digital photo can be printer on photo paper, however dye sublimation printing would probably reproduce a more true "film" like image.
You couldn't get me to go back to film with all the money in the world.

Can I blow your mind further? Digital cameras still can't see in color, they only see black and white. They can only measure the amount of light that hits the sensor in a 0 to 100, black to white gradient.

But each pixel on a cameras sensor has a pixel-sized color filter over it. Red, green or blue, inter-spaced evenly. That’s why if you've ever looked at a bare camera sensor is has that iridescent color to it.

With a red, green or blue filter over each pixel, the camera, only being able to measure white to black, can reference any 3 pixels and use the shades of grey that it sees to determine what color those pixels should be.

Ultimately the cameras thinking process is... "For this pixel...if I see grey #82 under the red filter, and I see grey #65 under the blue filter to the right and I see grey #15 under the green filter to the left... then what that really means is that I'm seeing magenta #42 and I should color this pixel a dark purple color. And it repeats that process for each pixel and artificially colors your photo in real time.

And with that in mind, since 3 sensor pixels are physically far larger than 1 silver halide crystal, even though a digital SLR camera sensor is about the same size as a 35mm piece of film... the old 35mm film is still a much higher resolution than even the best digital cameras today.

Check out "Bayer filter" on wikipedia for a better explanation.

Little correction about what film grain is:
By the random placement of the silver particules in the gelatin, there is a statical clumping that forms the familiar granular pattern that becomes visible when a negative is enlarged enough. Silver particles range in size from 0.2 um to 2.0 um, with an average size of 0.6 um, while film grain appears to ranges in size from 6 um to 30 um.

But how does the 'magic' work? It's not very complicated to explain. Light enters via the lens and hits the emulsion. When enough photons hit one grain of emulsion, the bond between silver and halide (mostly bromide) in a few silverhalide crystals changes. The film 'remembers' this photon. If you wait too long with developping, the electrons re-arrange again to their default state and the latent image blurrs.
For BW: The film is treated in the developper (eg hydroquinone in Kodak D76). Hydroquinone is a reduction agent. All silverhalide crystals that were excited by a photon get reduced (the Ag+ becomes Ag) and the finely dispersed silver looks black. After enough time (you could up the ISO of a film by extending the time spent in the developper) the developper was removed, the process was stopped by diluted vinegar and the fixing agent (thiosulfate) was poured in. Thio dissolves the unexposed silver halides. After that you had to rinse out all the chemicals for about half an hour.
For colour: colour film contains three layers (R, G and B sensitive) and each layer contains two compounds: silverhalide and a specific colour coupler.
After exposing in the camera, the film is put in the CN41 developper and the same thing happens as with BW. With just one exception: As the excited crystal oxidizes the developper, the oxidation product of the developper, reacts with the colour coupler inside the layer, thereby forming a cloud of colour.
For each lump of metalic silver, there now is a cloud of colour next to a metallic BW image.
The next step is BleachFixing, in which the metallic silver is bleached (oxidized) and the un-exposed silverhalide is removed again with thiosulfate. This is a tricky process since you want to oxidize the metallic silver yet you don't want to ruin the precious colourclouds..
Rinsing and drying 'as usual'.
Slides were similar. The exposed film is developped in the first developper (eg D76, a BW developper). The oxidised D76 does not react with the colour couplers so you only get a metallic silver BW image. Next the metallic silver is bleached out and the wet film is exposed to an intense light. Then it enters the second developping stage with a colour developper which produces oxidised 'waste' that reacts with the colour couplers to form the colour clouds.
After the second developper, the bleachfix and rinse baths end the process.
Colour couplers and developping agents were better hidden secrets than the nuclear launch codes... Each time Kodak invented a new process, Agfa and Fuji needed to find new couplers, since Kodak had patented its own couplers....
The process in reality is a little bit more complicated because the red colour of the carrier is used for something which I forgot (after 30 years)

You really don't need the bottle opener. Just slightly press the canister and pop off the bottom clamping ring. Then push the plastic tab and slide out the rolled up film. We used to tighten the roll prior to opening the can. Keep the clamp, so you can reload the canister with bulkfilm (from 100 feet rolls) and reclamp the cartridge.
The bubbling in the developer is with nitrogen. Air would destroy the developer (which is a mild reduction agent).
The darkrooms I worked in were all equipped with light bulbs. If a TL light breaks the dust will render the room unusable for months.
Night vision equipment was mainly used by maintenance engineers to see what's happening. A lot of things could go wrong in a huge factory that was run by a single VAX 11/750 and one PDP-11 per production unit and .lots of ladder-programmed PLC's.
The Fuji Frontier seems to be 'heavily influenced' by the Agfa MPS system, which in the late 80's was so advanced that the MPS was on the COCOM list and was not allowed to be sold to a non-NATO country. Luckily Fuji had a factory in Europe.
The MPS was a super machine. It took a roll of develloped film, make a scan of each frame, do some math and then come up with an average for the full strip of film. Based on that average, a base filtering was derived, which made 99% of the prints perfect at the first try. That was the end of the craftsman...

Using the small development tank is easy once you learn to do it in complete darkness (practice loading a worthless old film for a few days in a normally lit room, then practice a few times in a dark basement before risking a real film with low value attempts).  Once it's rolled into the spiral, just pour in and out chemicals without opening the tank.  Besides the tanks, you just need bottles and buckets.  No cutting the film until it's completely developed and you can see where the pictures are.

This took me back. I was an art major in college in '80s, and photography was my media. I spent a lot of time in darkrooms for those 4 years. I hadn't though of the smells and feeling of being in a darkroom in a long time.

And then, in the middle 1990s, I took a job with a big commercial photo lab here in Houston for a year while I was changing careers, so all that came back to me. That lab did most of the commercial work, including printing, for Houston and the surrounding area. We also did a fair amount of "retail" work. That lab is gone now, as film is so much less used. Like the lab you visited, we did not let any outsiders see our customers' work, but you can be sure we all looked at the really interesting stuff that came through the lab.

If you realy want to develop film and make it alive on paper, you can process it yourself at home. This is the real magic. In a dark room with one red bulb, watching your photo develop from negative to positive.

I watched the whole video and I can tell that if it's true that Film is coming back, it's for either nostalgia or hipster reasons., which is fine but there's nothing that film can do better when compared to digital photography.

All the reasons, mentioned in this videos are strictly subjective and emotional.

Now, I understand the satisfying feeling of seeing the development process but that's not the day to day for regular people. I'm old enough to remember using Film cameras and it was a pain in the neck to grab a 12 shot roll of film (because sometimes you couldn't afford a bigger one), take the pictures hoping that one of your fingers didn't get in the way or the exposure wasn’t too bad that the photo becomes unusable. Sometimes, only 6 or 7 out of 12 pictures were usable. Keep in mind that you would have to wait usually around a week to get to see your pictures and find out that you weren't able to capture what you intended.

By the way, Destin said that you can't get that Film effect on digital photos. Well, it's possible if you know what you're doing with professional software.

Anyways, I'm not disparaging Film by any means, I'm just baffled by all the fuss around indie/hipster stuff. If people want to use film, more power to them but don't claim it's better. Digital replaced it for a reason. Using film it's no different from using Vinyl records, 90's clothing or driving cars without power-steering.

With digital you just get into this mindset of snap a few hundred pictures and see what you get. With film I could go out for a day of shooting and not take 100 pictures but with digital you can do 100 in less than half an hour.

Briefly, my thoughts as to what's so special about silver based film photography:
1) the process involves hands-on craftsmanship, and produces a tangible piece of work;
3) the recent increased interest, is mostly due to a degree of nostalgia (e.g. baby-boomers reflecting on their younger years when photography was only film);
4) silver based photography was not the first photographic technology, and will eventually takes it's place alongside earlier processes.

Brought back a lot of memories from the 80s when I worked at the nations’s (maybe the world’s oldest photo lab, E. B. Luce Corporation in Worcester. We had a dip and dunk for E6 and roller transport for C41 film development. Our dip and dunk machine also used nitrogen bubbles for agitation, but because we developed so much film, gas canisters ran out too quickly, so we had a big tank of liquid nitrogen. My job was mostly making large photo murals (up to 52” (the largest material width) x 16’ (the width of my darkroom’ in my darkroom). I used a Durst 2,000 watt enlarger that could handle negatives and chromes up to 8”x10”.

There’s something I don’t quite understand about the video’s assertion: Indie doesn’t actually print photos, but instead they scan the film and convert it into digital photos, which may also involve digital alteration/touching up. So, if even film photos become digital, what’s the basis for the argument that film photos produce better quality images than totally digital photos? Is it because the film is able to pickup more photons than a digital camera? If so, isn’t the quality of the film image reduced or limited as it becomes processed (first through the scanner’s limits on what it can pickup, then through the conversion of that image to manageable digital files, then through the screen quality of the device you view the digital image on)? Is the scanner producing better images than a high quality digital camera? And is the scanner touchup software better than the software used for high quality digital photos? I’m not arguing against anything, but I legitimately didn’t see the video present how digitized film images are objectively superior in quality to purely digital images, whereas I did see plenty of subjective claims for superiority of film based on the experience one has while using or processing it.

This video takes me back to my high school days of my photography classes 35 years ago. And also my photo processing days at the local photo processing store 31 years ago.

My classroom had the dark room with the revolving door. A big heavy metal tube that easy to turn. We also had a developing room which we used the hand held developing cylinders of the film and then we had multiple exposure machines and then the print developing station with the four trays of chemicals to get our pictures. VERY old school processing. Like you saw in the movie Jaws 2.

In the store I worked at it was just two machines. The first to develop the film itself from the rolls. This machine had a little dark room box just big enough for your hands to slip through tight black velvet curtains (much like one of those medical lab boxes used in virus study). This box is used if the film is completely rolled up in the canister. I would use the "dimple" part of the canister to slam it down onto the box base to pop the flat cover off the canister, pull out the rolled film to find the end, slide the end through the slit in the canister (just like manufacturers did to sell the film), put the cover back on the canister, then pull everything out of the box. Then snip the tapered end off the film and use a special tape (much like car tail lens tape) to tape the film itself to a plastic 8x10 (approx.) card with old style punched holes on the edges for gears to grab and feed it into the processing machine. About ten minutes later the card and film exit out the back with fully processed film.

Next came the photo processing with the second machine. I literally processed one image at a time for each roll of film by inserting the film into a tray, like a microfiche machine, line up the edges of the negative to the hole in the tray, insert the tray into the machine lens which projected the image on a display down INTO the machine which I could view via a tint glass window on the base of the machine near the tray insert. Once it was lined up I would do a test print to see if color correction of brightness or contrast needing adjusting. Generally a test print would determine everything for the whole roll of film. If no adjustments were needed I would pull the tray out, moved the film over to the next frame, re-insert the tray, press the print button and repeat until the roll was completed. Then the machine would take each photograph printed from a roll of photo paper, cut the paper to size, run the paper through the chemicals and dryer and spit the paper picture out the side of the machine. It kind of made you feel like an engineer on the starship Enterprise. lol

If adjustments are needed, then multiple test prints are made to determine when adjustments are right. Adjustments were made via push buttons on the machine to add or subtract certain colors or brightness or contrast. Rolls that needed adjustments took longer to process because sometimes some frames of film needed more fine tuning based on what the image was on the negative. And average roll of film from the time it came into the store to the point of ready to pick up was around 30 minutes or less (sounds like pizza delivery). Adjustments film would take the full 30 minutes. But if I was busy and had many rolls to develop I would give the customers at least a full one hour response time because that was what was popular in those days. One Hour Photo Developing.

For me the preferance of film comes from several things. It is a physical process that is missing and can be messed up easily if you are not focused.  When shooting the photo you need to be in the moment more. You have to focus your mind on what you want from the photo. You have to adjust the camera itself to get things how you want it. The development is a physical process that if you do it yourself is very rewarding. Finally you end up with a physical image you can hold. A developed photo often actually has a rough texture you can feel with your finger tip when you run your hand over it. You do not get that printing a photo from a computer. I feel that rough physical feeling is part of what changes the look of the photo. It is refracting the image out in many directions depending on the texture, on the angle of those raised parts of the photo. If you take a printed digital photo and compair the same image on traditional photo paper they look different. I think the changes in color, changes in how you view things based on the texture of the paper evokes a feeling inside you. My mom passed away several years ago and I have a few printed photos and some digital photos. When viewing the printed photos of us I feel something different than the digital version of the same photo. It can't really be explained but I think anyone who has ever thought about it knows what I mean.

There's a word for that feeling you don't know how to describe... It's "analog". Film is to photos/video, what records and high quality reel to reel tapes are to audio/music. These things don't exist in nature as digital. Sound in nature moves in waves, not set steps made out of 1s and 0s. Our ears evolved to hear natural sound over millenia upon millenia, and our brains evolved to use that information in a certain way. Digital can approximate, and imitate, and the technology had improved, it's gotten better and better at imitating. But it's still just that. An imitation. Digital also suffers from compression, and color limitations. The compression can be less and less as technology advances, but it's still generally there, because as the tech and resolution advances, so do the file sizes get bigger. Meaning you can get super high quality digital photos today, still not the same as pure film, but if you're seriously into photography you might want to store full blown raw "lossless"(debatable) files. Which are just massive. You need some massive hard drives to be storing lots of those lol. I would argue respectfully that when this lab you visited does the scanning and conversion to digital files step, even though they're doing it with the utmost care, and using the best equipment available... You're still losing something of the original image during that conversion. It still ends up digital, which is going to result in at least a little bit of "lost in translation".. Many would argue that due to all the traditional steps, care, and love they put into the process up until that point, that it's just as good, or close enough where the human eye can't really tell the difference.. But there still IS some loss. Obviously if you want to store the photos on your computer, you need this. Computers only speak digital. But if you really want the true lossless experience, you need to go from taking the photos, all the way to the prints, without any digital steps. The old school way of making those photograph prints you can hold in your hand, and show to other people, would be transferred to the final medium optically using an optical enlarger, with the final medium being something most likely along the lines of a chromogenic print medium. This is 100 percent optical from beginning to end with zero digital steps... Basically the way they used to do it before computers or any form of digitizing were even available/possible. While I may be an old fashioned stick in the mud, I would definitely prefer my prints to be non-digital from beginning to end. I'd still get the film scanned, so I could have a digital reference on the computer for ease of storage, or if people who don't care about this sort of stuff want a copy, since it's much easier to just email them a file and so on. But when it comes to my original prints that I want to have in physical form, whether just to look at myself, show to other people in person, or make larger prints of, for display purposes (framed, mounted, whatever) I still really prefer direct optical enlargement and no digital anywhere in the "assembly line". At the end of the day, photos taken on Film, and developed properly before being scanned into a computer, are better. They just are. But no matter how much authenticity there is in the process, the second you scan them into a computer, they just become digital. Those copies you get via email, or special download link on your computer are "film taken, and developed" yes, but they're still digital photos at the end of the day if they exist on your computer at all. I don't mean this in a negative (lol) way. I just personally prefer my prints to be non digital at any point. I may be the only person on earth who's this weird, I don't know. I didn't catch it in the video, but does this lab do direct optical prints/enlargements, and then have the digital scans as an option/extra/alternative.. Or are all of their photos sent through the scanners, and the prints you get digitally scanned prior to printing? i.e. No option for optical enlargement and chemical process prints, leaving digital/computers/scanners totally out of the process?

I used to shoot slit-scan imagery on a very early motion control Oxberry Animation Camera stand. Hundreds of precisely positioned progressive images. If one were wrong, the whole sequence would have to be repeated. This could mean days of work. The whole process of sending it to "the lab" and waiting for processing and transfer to video prior to my being able to see it was nerve wracking! I had a pretty good rate of success, but would occasionally find myself starting a client project over again from scratch. Not the best of memories... but thanks for revisiting this wonderful analogue process.

It was such a wonderful thing when I got my first digital camera. Finally I wouldn't have to be so stingy with photography. I could experiment more, learn more, and take multiple pictures of one scene in case the first one didn't turn out. I would never have gotten into serious photography without digital. I have no desire to go back to film, especially because of the cost.

Destin, for those of us who grew up with film photography, we understand why it is so visceral.  Unlike digital photography where the photographer can take dozens if not hundreds of photos of a particular scene or subject, and then pick out the best photographs, film photographers have to take their time fine-tuning their shots, almost becoming intimate with the scene, because of the limited film in the camera.  Film photographers also have to be aware of the costs of developing films and making prints.  All this adds up to the need to take one's time composing the picture and the exposure.  In a real sense, digital photography has made us lazy about taking our time with each picture because we can happily snap away dozens of pictures without really putting a lot of thought into the composition of the photographs.  I'm just as guilty of this as anyone else.  Don't get me wrong; I like my DSLRs, but I do miss using film cameras!

You missed a lot of things:

1. how does exposure and forming of a latent image works, what IS a latent image?

The photosensitve cristals are made of silver halogenid, mostly bromid. So its AgBr. But is a salt and ionized just like NaCl. There are positive Ag+ ions and negative Br- ions.
A photon strikes out an electron from the Br- ion. These electrons got more energy and the are into the so called conduction band. Just like electrons (actually also those in conduction energy band) in metals these electrons can now move freely inside the crystal.
They move to centers of distubance in the crystal. Very good centers of distubance are other atoms like sulfur.
(-> a perfect AgBr crystal ist NOT light sensistive. Its nees a disrupted crystal structure and other atoms. These other atoms (e.g. for short time use mercury) make the crystals more sensitive)

So these places inside the crystal became negativ charged.

Freely moveable Ag atoms move to this placed and get reduced.
These Ag atoms stuck together. More than three form are stable cluster. These are the latent image. A tiny amount of metallic silver consist of few Ag-atoms.

2. development

Basically development reduces the AgBr to Ag. The developer agent (D) will be oxydized (DO).
The chemical (pseudo) formular is:

AgBr + H2O + D -> Ag + DO + HBr. (HBr is needed for development as well, it makes that the development does not affect unexposed crystals, so its also produced)

But the magic is this: the developer agents should work only on exposed AgBr crystals. And that is because its an autocatalytic process. It needs silver to start.
So everywhere where there is already metallic silver the developer reduce the rest of the crytal proportional to the already existing silver (latent image)
So developer amplifies the latent image.

3. color development

Additionally to the Ag, color dyes are formed. This is done by using so called color couplers. These are chemical parts of a dye that together with the oxidized developer agent forms a dye.
And this is kind of a lucky accident! There is one form of dyes that are usable for color photography. Where a cyan, magenta and yellow dye exist that consist of a chemical substance that is also a good developer. There is only one form of dyes (azo dyes) and one - only one! - substance that is also a good (black and white) developer. p-phenylendiamin. If this substance would not have exist, color photographie would be different.
And since this dyes are formed with oxydized developer agent this color image is proportional to the developed silver image.

This silver image is removed in color films. A so called bleach makes AgBr again from the Ag image, and this AgBr is remove together with the undeveloped ArBr by the fixer.
A bleach bath is kind of missleading. A better name would be "development reverser".
And I actually did this! I developed a color film with rodinal b/w. Scanned it. Than I bleached it and did a color development than. Its strange. But it works. In some kind it transforms the behaviour of the bw developer to the color film. But with color shifts.

There is a lot more to say. But thats the chemical process in short.

@ 2:33 I once took a photography class on the AFB where I worked at the time, and got to develop and print the pictures I took. We were working in B&W as color film is a more complex process. Using the enlarger to expose the final print, I got to crop my photos in a way that I thought they should be printed, rather than having a lab just print the entire frame. There was one picture I took on color film, the lab did not print because they thought the picture did not come out. I told them to print it anyway, and sent it back. It was a single strand of spider silk with a rainbow sheen on it where the sunlight reflected off it.. It looked spectacular when I got the print back. When I got my first digital scanner, I was able to take those negatives and digitize them, marking off those areas I wanted in the final image. BTW, there are some colors that film captures better than digital. I had one picture of a purple flower. Film captured it, but in the digitized image the flower was blue.

@ 13:03 In a B&W lab, film must be kept in the dark, but in the print process, the print paper is only sensitive to blue light, so we had an orange light we could use to see by. Opening the cans for the film and loading it into the developer frames was done inside a light tight bag. Color prints are sensitive to all wavelengths, so color labs require total darkness.

@ 34:41 I have seen videos that suggest that it's easier to get high def digital videos from film, and from upscaling digital captures. For instance, the TV series Andromeda was shot on 35mm film. The DVDs created from that were intended for DVD players, not 1080p. It is easier to go back to the original film footage and get good results for the higher resolution than it is to upscale 480p. BTW I'm a fan of the Andromeda series. Unfortunately for me, someone decided they needed the money more than I needed the DVD's. I spent over $1000.00 US getting those as they came out, and lost it all in one swell foop. All of those DVDs were first run. Note, one of the things I loved about those was, you could see the graininess of the film in the video in low light situations, but somehow, it all came together to give a better experience, like watching a movie in the theater.

Oh boy, how did you get my Canon AE1 Program??? ;-) I loved (and still do celebrate) this camera - one of the best if not "the best" analog camera of that days! No AutoFocus every gorilla could get some ultra-sharp photos, no "if you want to get landscape shots just press here" button and everything is done for you.
In fact, the very best of it is the way you could make mistakes, you could either avoid that mistakes or just make use of "mistakes regarding to accuracy of showing up things oh photo" to express something. When doing such things with software it feels like kind of cheating. When you compose things by setting all by hand it feels like "It always were there for real, it just needed someone to let show it's real nature"... ;-)
And - not to forget - you just could not afford to just shoot hundreds of photos for "the one out of a million" shots. You had to think of "how could I achieve that effect" and then..... wait ...... wait ...... for a week or even longer to get the rewarding moment of seeing your artwork. The moment you first saw the developed negatives to consider if they were well done or did not work out - that was so rewarding! No comparison to the shoot-n-click feeling of digital cameras. Digital cameras do have big pro's also, no doubt, but there's something "natural", something I can't really explain why I loved analog photography. Maybe it is the kind of archaic processing of taking and composing a shot?
You're an incredible photographer, Destin!

(Opinion) 32:13 Yes he is being very aggressive and sitting with the film draping his street clothing. Who knows what the floor looks like too. What is the resolution of the scanners? Are they recording the grain in the film? If not, how much detail is lost for the sake of file sizes or scanner capabilities? Are they using ICE technology to remove all the lint and scratches from handling film like that? (There is a nice (V800?) Epson next to him for big film. I wonder how he cleans those?)

I'm sure some of the film being processed is not just special effect weddings. There are priceless images going through those machines. Those images are my biggest concern.

35mm is much harder to keep clean because of the relative amplification. (35mm was always an excellent compromise using movie film. That size of negative is technically already obsolete. You can manipulate digital images in software to get those effects. Larger formats, starting with 645 would take enormous file sizes if scanned to the point of rendering film grain (analog information?) That kind of detail is still arguably still best recorded in analog media.

What's the point of going through the manufacturer control strip process if someone is sitting at a monitor, subjectively altering the tones before the client gets the results?  What are their practices for medium format?

When you study wet/dry darkroom photography, aside from learning composition, (then you can do whatever you want), you are vested in knowledge of what you're getting rendered on the film. That means you know the film's dynamic range, among other qualities. The range is very narrow compared to digital media. (Look up the zone system where you test and know what to expect when you push or pull the development to control the contrast in your dark room.) Otherwise you typically bracket above and below what you need, later you can make composites in software, etc.

Hello Dustin. Photographer since about 1965, pro since about 1971. Cameras I still have is an 8X10 box camera, a 4x5 Speed Graphic press camera complete with the very rare xenon flash. It used a 450 volt dry cell to directly charge the capacitor. The battery impedance was so high that it took almost a minute to recharge the capacitor. The batteries being a thing of the past, I long ago designed and built an inverter to that ran on Gates Cyclonic Pure Lead Grid batteries. I have a Canon something-or-other SLR and the creme'-de-la-Creme, a Kodak Medallist II.

This camera was designed for the Army AirForce as an aerial recon camera. The war over, Kodak released the camera to the public. Dad bought this camera in 1946 for $700 (I have the receipt). It has the best glass of any camera I've ever used. Unfortunately it uses 620 film. Same as 120 except for the spools. For years, I've respooled 120 film onto the 620 film spools but no more. The reason is that the currently manufactured films are basically garbage. Gone are Fuji Velvia and Kodachrome 32 and 64. That's ASA (ISO) 32 and 64.

My C-41-based Kodacolor photos faded to cyan inside of 20 years. Preserve your digital scans. OTOH, the Kodachrome lantern slides that Dad shot in the 40s are still as fresh as if shot today. Mom was a model. I have a Kodachrome photo of Mom holding a spray of red roses that Dad took on their 1st anniversary that is still perfect.

If you think about it a little, it should be obvious why film looks better. Practically infinite pixel-equivalent resolution, even with Tri-X. The way the image sensor in a digital fiddles with data multiplexing. The processing the camera does to produce the jpg unless you're shooting in RAW mode and post-processing. You have some fine digital cameras. Why don't you try RAW mode and post-processing on the computer?

Digital can be as good as film. I've seen the output of a 200 megapixel studio camera, post-processed by a very skilled technician. Awesome!

I have lived and seriously experienced both film and digital and the best comparison I can give you is a model T Ford and a Tesla. One feels different from another but it depends on what you want. If you want to feel history behind you and nostalgia, yes Model T. If you want to get somewhere fast with hard to remember directions - Tasla. I remember running out of film while failing to capture monumental shots. I remember sitting in the living room, covered in blankets, trying to put undeveloped film into a plastic canister unto a track for developing. There were so many failure points in film. So many frustrations. Fats forward to the digital age. Holy smokes. With a few extra batteries you can shoot thousands of shots. You can shoot in RAW. Your ISO is insane, your low light capabilities are insane. You can save on dual memory cards. After shooting, you can immediately upload your data to a hard drive, a flash drive or a cloud. You're not afraid of failure as much. Temperature is no problem. Time is no problem. Now, if you were born in the digital age, you view film as something exotic and precious and to a degree it is but if your goal is to capture, to successfully capture good shots, digital has the advantage. One good argument can be made against digital is resolution but that's a horse of another color or a camera of a different format. They make medium format digital cameras, so the comparison should be between medium format film and medium format digital. Anyway... great video, well executed and thank you for your hard work, Destin!

God knows how long it took for me to take the 24 pictures on the roll. Then have to send it off in the post to have a company develop it. And wait for it to come back in the post. And find I hadn't held the camera steady and every single picture was blurred. Heart breaking. I also found loading and unloading the camera stressful, "was the canister spindle moving?", "have I wound the film all the way back into the canister, am I going to open the back and find half the film still in the camera?"

There's also a certain irony about saying how wonderful film is, and then sending it off to be developed and have them digitise it so you can share it easily.

Back in my student days (early 90's), for a job, I used to run one of these one hour processing labs on a weekend. Good times. Setting things up in the morning, calibration prints, test strips to determine developer levels, replenish and test periodically, all that stuff.

Interesting that they pry the film open like that...I used to use a thin double metal strip "leader catcher" tool that you inserted into the film holder....rotate the film gently and the catcher snags the sprocket holes and you pull the film out.....easy peasy.... Then pop it into the light-tight loader hatch of the film developer. About 1/200 would not catch which required opening the film holder in a darkbox (just your hands go in) and transferring the film into a special dummy plastic film holder for loading. Good memories here, but their process seems somewhat complicated....?

p.s. Noritsu film developer and Fuji printer. And regular visits from the silver reclamation dude, who paid us for all our waste liquids, because the silver content was high enough to be economical for him.

p.p.s I was the only fool brave enough to crack open 110 plastic film holders (in the dark box) from the old instamatic cameras, and load them into a dummy film holder. Which meant we got all the legacy 110 business because everyone else directed their customers to our shop. Saturday mornings I had a pile of 110's to crack open after setting up the machines. Never lost a-one ever LOL and I could do it with my eyes closed (not that eyes make any difference when the film is in the darkbox LOL).

Romanticizing about film cameras is nice but to try to claim that you are doing something more, or getting more out of taking pictures with a film, camera is to forget what it was to only have film cameras and actually need to get a shot. If you weren't a hard core photographer you just had a point and shoot or a manual that you don't know if you got right. You'd get the pictures back and they'd be out of focus, be pictures of your thumb, be way over or under exposed, be blurry because you didn't have the right speed of film, then you get prints and hope the photo lab didn't do something screwy, then you pay way to much getting multiple prints to give out to family, Etc etc etc.
There are 100's of reasons that film cameras have essentially gone away and no, they are not coming back, regardless of how many hipsters team up with Christopher Nolan. I'm someone who grew up with a dark room in our house (father taught photography) and while I can be nostalgic about aspects of it, when I look at the thousands of moments and memories I captured that wouldn't have ever been shot (or might have but could have been 'missed') if I had film, I do not miss it a bit.

I think is the grain and the fact that is a 100% analogical process. The thing that captures the light is a layer of microscopically small grains randomly arranged and of various sizes, not a grid of perfect squares. There's not even a resolution, as it is analogical, basically infinite capture of detail. It's just light being captured as it comes in, no post-processing, no 'beauty filter' that over-sharpens edges or turns skin into a plastic texture, it's closer to how our own eyes work. Because those are grains, it gives it a quality of being drown on paper by a very skilled artist. The fact that is an analog process makes us interact with it directly and thus increase the feeling of attachment. You know, something similar happens with old CRT TVs and CRT monitors. Try to watch content or play video games on a CRT if you can, you'll be surprised.

Destin, you might find a professional photographer that develops their own camera film negatives to prints. That is a fascinating and very fun process from start to finish. I learned how to process all of my own film through my wife. She was an amateur photographer that moved here to Texas from Montreal Canada. She was into photography and "hockey". We had to use black & white "recorder" film that was used in low light environments, (covert surveillance), & such. Our ice hockey in Houston at the time was in our old coliseum with abysmal lighting. Black & white film was all that we could use for that reason. We could take our photos & "push" the negatives, through timing in the developing bath, to achieve a descent finished product. Anyway, thanks for taking me into your "wayback machine" on this journey of film processing. Your the greatest.

Up until 2017 I had a darkroom in my closet, with a Durst 4x5"(CLS450). If you just want to develop film and scan it at home, you don't need a darkroom. You can load the film on the spiral in a dark room or inside a loading bag. It's like a jacket, you put your arms inside the sleeves and load the film in the torso area. B&W film is no problem because it's done at room temperature, but color films can be more tricky, if you care about accurate colors. C-41 and E-6 are done at higher temperatures (around 38C). Cross processing is an alternative if you don't care about accurate skin tones etc.

I used film cameras a long time - 110, 220, 35mm, APS. I love digital and find it superior. I don't feel like film is magical - just different, and, really, inferior. Just like 'audiophiles' who swear vinyl is 'warmer', etc. It simply doesn't reproduce the same sound as lossless digital. In both cases I think it is just because it is what a lot of people are used to. Film looks 'right' - because we are used to it. It is what we expect. And digital looks different - and humans tend to prefer what they're familiar with.

The 'special look' from film - photos and motion pictures - is really imperfections. Film grain, limitations of the chemical processes, etc. I remember needing to decide if I really wanted to burn 1/36 of my photos on a shot - and maybe I didn't take a photo because I wasn't sure it was going to work, etc. Or I did, and it didn't work so it was wasted. With digital I can snap a shot whenever I want - and if it isn't a good photo, I can delete it. Simple.

I have a lot more memories documented since I went digital - and they're accessible. I have boxes full of old photos that haven't been looked at in years, even decades. Maybe I'll scan them someday - paying for a service isn't cheap, and doing it myself is tedious. I know there are some great shots in there, documenting some special times - but they're effectively inaccessible right now. My digital library I can search any time I want.

As a geek I appreciate the process and the engineering that went into figuring all of this out and making film work in the first place. It was a major achievement, and is still fascinating. But I don't romanticize film any more than I do NTSC television, CRTs, dial-up modems, etc. They had their day.

This was an awesome video and approached the subject of film photography from a great perspective. How interesting the process is, how it's almost a lost art and how different it is to what people are used to. And all that in a non-hipster way, thinking that it's inherently better because reasons. With film photography, it's exactly the same situation as with audio. Objectively speaking, digital is superior. You can capture much more information, encode it perfectly, present it perfectly, it won't degrade with use, it sounds exactly how it should. But there is something about vinyl records that's almost magical. It's the same music, but it has noise, it has grain, it has a high noise floor, it differs ever so slightly each time you hear it. It should be perceived as worse, but it's not. It's the countless tiny imperfections that give it character. It doesn't have to be superior, and it isn't, but it works. Same thing with amplifiers. Compare a modern solid state amp to a tube amp. The tube one has distortion, has noise (sometimes), it audibly messes with the music. But there's something magical about it. We, as a species, are losing on too much on our quest to perfection. Sometimes, a little imperfection is all it takes to make something good into something great.

Great video! I remember when I did an internship around 14 years ago in a Fujifilm photo factory for my Electrical Engineering (pre) Degree. Most of it was indeed all digital at that time already, but the remains of the film era were visible throughout the factory, and still one line was running film for a few hours per week. They showed me pictures from the 'golden times' for film. Fascinating to see. All films were melted together in one large film strip, 100s of meters long which traveled through the factory with a system consisting of rollers. Running through the developer baths etc. At highest point they had 8 lines running 16 hours a day producing kilometers of film. Also the printing process was done on a long ribant (if that's the correct translation) several 100s meters long. At the end of the production line there were these cutter machines which could cut around 20 photos per second if I remember correctly before the ladies put them in the bags to be shipped out. It rarely happened that the film broke which caused a production stop and sometimes resulted in unusable film, but it happened. I had a great time there.

Also thanks for the verse every time at the end, I'm always waiting for it to see what you have come up with. Love it.

There is a very old story about the development of film going back to the ortho glass plate days, before panchromatic film. Kodak regularly ran test on emulsion batches to check the film speed and consistency. One batch of gelatin tested, proved to have a much faster speed than it should. So they tracked this back to goats from Armenia eating wild garlic. For some reason this changed the film speed.     I have no idea if this story is true, but it is so weird that it might be.
