My first camera was a 1965 Nikon F that my father gave me in 1977. It was formerly owned by a photographer from Life magazine. It was completely manual. You had to set the F stop, aperture, focus all by hand (or eye). No previews. You had to work from memory and experience based on the type of film (speed, grain, manufacturer, developer, etc.). (For example Fuji film had slightly different characteristics than Kodak film and different photographers leaned toward one or another based on personal bias.) The body of the camera was steel. The internals were dampened. You could drop it from shoulder height onto cement and (probably) wouldn't kill the body, though the lens might not survive. It was made for the field for professional photojournalists, and you can still get lenses and film for it.

My father taught me how to quickly "bracket" shots. That is, to take a picture with slightly more and less exposures so when the film came back from the lab, you could choose the best of the three. Likewise, rather than spend money developing a roll into slides or prints, he taught me to get "contact sheets" developed where the negatives were all printed out on one large sheet and then you would mark that up and tell the developer to only develop the ones you wanted.

In short. It was a process that could take weeks. When digital cameras came out I jumped. Instant gratification. Virtually unlimited options in post and the tools kept getting better every year.

The net? Coming from analog to digital gave me skills to frame and focus and be more "careful "about which shots I take and which I leave behind. But I disagree with you about your subjective impressions about the benefits of film over digital. The key difference happens inside the head and soul of the photographer, not the device in the hands.

I have a hypothesis that the "special feeling" from old film compared to modern film has to do with sharpness.

The newer technology (particularly LED monitors / digital cams) can make images incredibly sharp, which makes certain colors seperate very distinctively.

However older technology (particularly cathode ray tubes / film cameras) have colors which blend together, making the image's colors somewhat blur in between.

Back in the late 70's I started processing film in my somewhat extensive home darkroom and had a good number of clients. I did the film processing and printing (actual photographic printing with photographic paper (works like film). Then with a partner I opened an actual commercial photo lab employing film processing equipment almost exactly like what's seen in this video. Things were very much different back then - the negatives were processed and actually printed using a photographic "printer" that projected the negative image onto a roll of photographic paper that was then fed into another processor that developed the positive images on the paper in a very long strip which was then cut up into individual photographs by another machine - there was nothing digitized - that technology didn't exist at the time. We also processed color slide film which was a positive image. Oh my, do I miss those days! Seeing this video almost brought tears to my eyes. I really enjoyed this presentation! Awesome. Thanks.

About the time I lost interest in photography was about the time I acquired a digital camera.  As I started shooting film, I've renewed my interest in photography.  I had always enjoyed night photography.  Various lamps we use in street lights color shift on film differently than we perceive with our eyes.  HPS lamps shift toward pink.  Metal halide lamps shift toward blue.  Mercury vapor lamps shift toward green.  The exaggerated colors just make night scenes magical.  Digital cameras do a fairly good job of keeping colors true, and therefore not nearly as interesting.

I took two years of traditional photography in high school and loved developing my film in the dark room and working the chemicals. Then i used to work in the photo department of my local Target back when that was a thing some years ago. It was fun working the meager editing tools they offered to color correct photos. This episode is giving me some crazy nostalgia.

I came up on film, so none of this is really magic to me. One thing that's left out of this is the one-roll tank processing that most of us did (yes, we processed our own). Also, the enlarging and printing processes here are digital, not analog.

You'd have a whole array of techniques to study in the hand-printing process. Little manipulations, like pulling the developing image out of the tray and blowing hot breath on a part of the print that wasn't coming in dark enough (heat accelerated development). Or the worst case scenario, when you'd overexposed the print and it started coming in way too fast. Generally, you'd just pull it out at that point (why waste chemicals on a dead print?).

All that said, I don't shoot film any more. Just like I don't use tape any more for recording. You come to realize, at a point, that you've gained so much more than you've lost, particularly if you're doing it for money. How many shots did I lose rewinding the film into the cart before I could pop it out and thread another one? Oh, so many. How many shots do I nail today because I can bang off 10 fps? Plenty. Watching someone's smile develop until BAM--there it is, the perfect maximum extension of an expression.

So, yes. I can see the nostalgia. Hey, I have a wall of vinyl...I get it. I like still putting my hands on records I bought in college, half of which never made the leap to digital. But is vinyl objectively better? No. Not by a country mile. And is film objectively better? No, by the same standard. I bought my first CD player in 1983, and even with the relatively rough converters compared to today, I will never forget the first time I heard a digital classical recording on it. Free of clicks, pops...no noise but the air moving in the room. It was like a veil had been lifted. And now, with modern AD/DA converters? It's just even more superior.

The one weakness of current digital cameras is, ironically, the S L O W rate at which the manufacturers are willing to add features. And the reason for that, at least according to a Canon engineer I had a long conversation with, is the general conservatism of the leading companies. This engineer (only recently retired) moved to the medical division because, in his words, there was more opportunity to advance imaging improvements that would be subjected to years of alpha/beta testing in consumer/pro photography markets.

I guess the only other thing I miss about printing in analog world was darkroom time. It was dark in there. And there were girls. So, yeah.

Awesome video Destin! One possible explanation for why film appears superior to digital has to do with the difference between random and regular sampling. It's actually a really cool concept that that touches on a lot of really important and powerful tools that are used all around us!

Imagine a 1Hz cosine wave that is regularly sampled once each period, only at the start of the wave (amplitude = 1). We would never be able to accurately estimate the frequency of the wave because of all of the aliases (1hz, 2hz, 3hz...) that would result in the same set of samples that are all equally likely. If instead we sample the wave at a random time each period then, over time, if the signal is stable, we can get a great estimate of the frequency of the wave and blow the Shannon-Nyquist sampling theorem out of the water!

Our brains are constantly reconstructing the world from sparse and incomplete observations so random sampling (film - random arrangement of crystals) results in a better overall reconstruction over regular sampling (digital - regularly spaced photosensors). A similar analogy could be made for vinyl vs digital audio.

What I can say is, there aren't many digital pictures that I remember, but I remember hundreds, if not thousands of film pictures I've taken. The difference for me, other than color saturation and contrast between film and digital is investment. There's a financial and emotional investment to film that I don't feel with digital, or at most I rarely feel it. I can lose a digital image and get over it. It's the realization that you only have a limited amount of shots that made every single aim-and-snap of the camera ought to capture "the moment" as good as possible. Those times that you wondered how you looked during the shot then ended up with bunny ears. Those moments that you felt you looked good during the shot but ended up a dud one (ended up a blank shot). The sorrow of getting the whole "roll" inadvertently got exposed or got contaminated, rendering the whole film a useless acetate sheets. Great video!... I'm almost 66 years old, and used to work at Kodak Research Labs in Rochester, NY for several years. This video took me back to my days at KRL when I worked on Ektachrome film product development in buildings 59 and 69 at Kodak Park along with approximately 7,000 other scientists, engineers, and technicians. Building 59 had a couple of completely dark floors where the experimental film coating machine rooms were located.

Part of my job there as a technician was to retrieve experimental film emulsions from a huge refrigerated area, and then deliver them on a cart to various experimental film coating machine technicians located in the completely dark floors of building 59. The hallways leading to those rooms were also completely dark, so it took some doing to navigate one's way to various specific experimental coating machine rooms.

Once the experimental films were coated with emulsion, I would then take them back to my lab for subsequent processing and testing (via sensitometric, densitometric, pressure, spectral sensitivity, accelerated aging, and picture tests). We would then compare our new, improved experimental films to current Kodak product, as well as to our competitors. It was definitely interesting work.

Ok, so first: Find a black and white darkroom you can use, and have someone teach you to manually develop some black and white pictures. If you think film is a good feeling compared to digital, hand developing (which isn't really practical with color) is even better! With black and white, you can make adjustments that impact the outcome during development. It's absolutely fascinating.

Second, my personal take is, digital is good if all you want to do is remember something or record something. It's also good when you have to get a good picture, because you can take a ton of shots and pick the best. It's a good industrial process for recording moments. Film is good for fine art photography. It's good when your goal is to produce art rather than merely recording moments or getting the perfect shot. With film, you have to accept that you probably aren't going to get the perfect shot, but because you have limited resources, you still have to make the absolute most of it. In digital photos imperfections can be viewed as laziness, but with film they are character. And, when you do get a perfect picture on film it is so much more valuable, not necessarily in money, but in sentimental value. One of my best pictures of all time is a black and white I took from a bridge going over railroad tracks. I was trying to get a scenic picture of some mountains in Alaska, and the bridge was the best view. The mountain pictures turned out terrible, as usual (too much dust in the air), but after snapping several pictures of the mountains, I looked down at the tracks, and on a whim took two pictures, one straight, and one with the tracks going through the frame diagonally. Those black and white images of the tracks were absolutely perfect, with good depth (despite the tracks only being a few inches high), just the right amount of reflection, perfect shadows, and flawless focus. They were the only frames on that entire roll of film worth keeping, and they are still some of my favorites. (I took those pictures as part of a black and white photography class, and everyone was really impressed, and I didn't even realize those would be the star of that shoot, until I developed them and saw what I had done. I used one of those pictures in the final portfolio for the course, and it helped earn me an A in the course.)

I realize not everyone will agree with me, and I've seen digital photographs worthy of classification as fine art, but film photography feels to me more like a medium of fine art than digital photography, because it is higher risk.

On a side note, my favorite film ever was some 90mm film some other student was using in the blackroom when I was taking that course. Larger film gets higher resolution, and while 35mm film has pretty decent resolution (especially if you can manage ISO 100, which has much smaller grain size), 90mm film projected on the same page size is so clear. That guy's photos were so gorgeous, because they were so smooth and clear! I really hope to eventually get a 90mm camera, so I can do photographic art like that!
I 100% prefer digital and think this preference for film is largely a nostalgia thing, but the science involved is still cool.

Film is magic, film has a grain, digital media has noise. Noise and grain look completely different and enlarging an underdeveloped film gives a complete different effect from enlarging an underexposed digital camera's picture.
Film also have different forms and sizes of grain. Kodak developed the T-grain which is more triangular .
With the color film, different companies use different filter in the film resulting in a different color style. Fuji film was known for it's brilliant green colors, Kodak (if I remember well) was more red oriented. Fuji film was mostly chosen for wedding photos by a lot of photographers over here.
I still remember when the scanners were introduced at a photo fair in Germany. They showed how enlarging a photo on a scanner could even reveal the grain of the film. Even though the scanner does introduce some digital noise, the scanning resolution is small enough to make sure that the magic of the grain in the film is still what defines the quality of the photo you get.

I started with film. Shot slide and colour neg, processed my own B&W, worked in the darkroom and was a real geek about film grain and colour, etc. And there is a visceral feel to the process that one doesn't get with digital. That said, I honestly think much of the draw for film today is the novelty, the natural cycle of retro trends.
People talks about the ease of use of digital making people less deliberate, but I see it as expanding my experimentation. Ansel Adams said: 'The negative is the score, and the print is the performance.' Digital gives me a symphony to play that score that film can't, not in colour at least.
My creativity, my focus and my voice came with digital. I'm not saying that makes it better than film, but I do think that it is more the person than the medium that makes the choices.

i was at uni 1982-1984 when i did photography, all black and white, i then went on to work in computer animation, i've done a top of the pops titles and loads of BBC work - the planets series (2000) for instance.

when i started out the second company i worked for was CFX, in soho, london, UK, we used to shoot from a cathode ray screen with 4000 line reesolution, onto to film, we used coloured gels in front of a mitchell camera to make colour from the basically black and white screen, and you had to shoot one pass of say red, rewind the film, change the colour gel, say green, shoot the film again, and repeat for all colours, then you'd send it to the lab and find out ONE FRAME was wrong and have to do it all again.

we would load rolls of 300ft or 400 ft film inside black bags, doing it by feel. if you wanted to make it look like one thing passed in front of another (this was all wire frame graphics) you would have to shoot a matte film, like a black square that would block out some of the wire frame to look like it was solid, so you'd load two or even three rolls of film on top of each other and go through the process as above, called bi-pak, one frame at a time, click, advance, click, advance, and hope it was right.

night vision - cool, but we used red or yellow light at uni....

i've probably thrown them all out but once upon a time i had BOXES of test strips for colour tests, literally dozens of albums full of 35mm film with different colours clients could use to decide how their "wire frame graphics" would look. i worked with wireframe from about 1982 till i guess 2000 when full colour, 3D rendering became common. bernard lodge, who did wotk on blade runner, used to take the wire frame and do hand animation over the top of it, making wire frame look 3D and cartoony.

you can see my crappy photography on instagram, and if you scroll back far enough (i exceed at everything) computer graphics too - @harrynicholas1 i have a youtube channel of guitar and computer graphics i've done, both my own and some pro.

It's not true that no amount of digital editing can give you that feeling, and also it's easy describable. Here's the list:
- No jpg or other codec artifacts (good modern digital cams can do this, with low iso and shooting raw).
- Grain instead of noise. The sulfer grain looks granular, not noisy.
- In some photo's it's the on camera flash that gives it an old-school look.
- You've got all the vintage (sometimes cheap) lens effects, like flares, aberration, colorbleeding etc. You can use a vintage lens on a modern camera.
- The color shifts from the actual filmtape make for a filmlook. This is easy reproducible in a photo editing software.
- And you've got all the ways in which the development or the exposure of the photograph to sunlight shifts or washes colors. You can have one color wash out while the others stay good. Or maybe you dropped some water on the photo somewhere.

It's true that a combination of all these things happen just by using film. And that a simple instagram filter doesn't give you that same exact effects. But if you give me a random analogue film I'm pretty sure I can recreate the exact same feeling. Except for all the surprises you get when you finally develop your roll ^^. That's worth something too.

Eons ago, I used a changing bag for putting film in the developing tank. It was a zippered (double bag, double zipppers) bag with tight elastic cuffs. You'd put the film, the tank and reel, a can (punch type) opener and a small pair of scissors in the bag, insert your hands into the bag and push the tight cuffs up onto your forearms. Working by feel, you pop the film canister open with the can opener, spool the film onto the reel, cut the tape fastening the end to the original film spool, and pop the reel into the tank. Then you put on the light tight lid, take everything out, and proceed with developing the film. I started developing film in grade 10, and continued to do so until I shifted to digital. Think I still HAVE that developing tank somewhere .... thanks for the reminder on how much fun film is.

There is an anecdote that was missed about the film in this video. During world war two, Kodak was getting complaints about film coming out fogged when processed. Kodak investigated the issue and found that the film had been exposed to radiation. They had linked it to the government's "munitions testing," which was, in fact, the Manhatten project. Kodak complained about it, threatening to sue. Instead, the government agreed to alert Kodak when a test was going to go off to protect their film. This agreement lasted decades. The government gave nuclear details, including weather patterns, predicted fallout, and radiation levels, to the film industry before even letting the public know of the dangers.

It is quite an interesting story. I highly recommend looking it up.

I grew up in Rochester, New York, home of George Eastman and the birthplace of the Eastman Kodak Company, the pioneer of bringing film photography to the masses. Pretty much everyone in my family worked at Kodak in one capacity or another for some period of time - in fact I daresay there was a time when everyone in Rochester either worked at or knew somebody that worked at Kodak; that company was the lifeblood of the city for many decades. I remember a story my dad recounted of doing some painting work at the Kodak headquarters, trying to navigate through dark hallways illuminated only by dim red marker lights in order to prevent destroying film in production. You had to walk with your hand touching the wall to keep from wandering off into the darkness, lol.

They made what proved to be a disastrously poor call to shun digital photography, claiming it would never catch on because the picture quality was too poor, despite having invented the first practical digital camera in the 70s... In hindsight that was obviously incorrect and it precipitated the collapse of the company which largely brought the city down with it. I live in Chicago now but have a lot of pride still for my hometown - despite it admittedly being a bit of a shithole these days - and I sing its praises every chance I get as it was an incredibly important city historically, with Kodak chief among the accomplishments as well as Xerox and their photocopier!

Seeing this video, in 2021, discussing with excitement and wonder the technology that was a cornerstone of my hometown for a century before it was largely forgotten about, and the thousands of commenters fascinated by it as well, is making me bizarrely emotional. My grandfather worked at Kodak for most of his life and I imagine if he were still alive he would be taken aback by the interest on display (and probably also vindicated as he refused to admit the scale of the blunder Kodak made by not embracing digital photography when they had the chance, lol).

Maybe this will mark the start of a resurgence in film photography and allow Kodak to reclaim their throne! I should buy some stock, haha... doubtful.

I have been a photographer since 1978.I am not sure if being an assistant in 1978 is a photographer yet, but that's when I started. Within a year as an assistant, I could shoot meaningful commercial images, develop either 35mm or 120 B&W film(in the case of 120...18 rolls at a time), and contact sheet on B&W paper for the client to see the same day. I would shoot in the morning, develop/contact during the two hour lunches and, after the Art Director picks the pics...make a few 11x14's for the Art Director to take home.

I love this subject.Maybe seek out how transparency film is processed. It's called E-6 chemistry. Be sure to include the power of the 'Clip Test'...every Professional Photographer's Personal Lab.

Lastly, check out what happens to B&W film when processed and the 'chemist' forgot to add hardener to the fixer...not a pretty sight.

I worked in a C-41 one hour photo lab in the 2000s. We had a Fuji machine that we fed one roll at a time. Saturday mornings I ran those Fuji test strips, we had a device in the lab to check the density of the results. I'd then make adjustments to the chemistry if neccesary. They didn't trust many people with making chemistry adjustments, just me and the manager.

Our scanner and printers were Noritsu, different models than they're using at Indie, but same software. Seeing the Noritsu software on-screen was a real throwback for me. I saw 10s of thousands of photos through that software. My hands twitched, apparently somehow I might still have the muscle memory of the keyboard shortcuts.

I think some of the magic of film is that it can make images without human intervention. I loved when people would bring a roll of film that had been sitting in a drawer for twenty years, the resulting blotches and other effects were mesmerizing. Against the rules, I saved scans of some of that stuff, still have them, still think it's cool. It's just the layers of the film breaking down, and light leaks, but it's great art.

When you do intentionally expose and develop film, you're participating in a magic interaction between chemistry and light that you're not quite in control of, it's fun and unpredictable. I'm going to go buy some film, put it in my 40 year old camera with a sketchy light meter, and see if we can't accidently get the exposure right and stumblee into a great image.

I always used to have a ticking clock in my darkroom to provide an audible location reference for loading films. I know some larger multi-person darkrooms used a metronome to cover a wider area and be heard above the ventilation fan noise.

The coolest thing about film to me is the direct line of physical connection.  The film reacts to the the actual visual event photons right there at the moment of time of the shot, the negative is directly connected to an enlarger print that supplies an image that you can hold in your hand --- a direct, physical connection to history.  I held civil war tintypes from my grandmother in my hands that were actually there in the moment. I used to work in a photo lab in the 70's and early 80's. Dip & Dunk machines were very common because they could handle multiple film formats (110 up to 120), as opposed to roll film processors which only worked on a single format (i.e 35MM). We also used night scopes with infra-red safe-lites, so we could see what we were doing in the total darkness. To paraphrase...."I love the smell of stop-bath in the morning....it smells like Victory!". I also have switched to digital cameras, but still have a couple of Nikon F's and a 120 Twin Lens reflex...that I will never get rid of, and still have all my Paterson developing tanks. Great video!

SyQuest became a very popular medium for transfer, 44 or 88 MB in size. Networks and servers were not quite strong enough at the time fast nor big. Its just the real beauty of film is locked in the fact that it's not a matrix grid where a chip is putting a value, it's a more noisy resolution that goes down to the atomic level and can capture something within the moment itself with the very photons it emitted. The power of noise in a work is noticeable if subtle - something traditionally designed and printed just looks different to something made on a computer - for so many reasons.

IMO the real discovery is when you properly apply both tools and realize the value of both, instead of disposing of one for the other. the flexibility and accuracy of a digital rendering is useful in so many ways, but analogue systems should never be underestimated as it is about as close to nature as you can get with a machine, and nature is the world we live in.

There is a reason that the first photo ever made has a magical level of clarity considering it was quite literally the first, and remastered film from the 60s/70s can look better than stuff we make today simply because it was shot on film and not processes through another system.

I wonder if your sense of there being more depth in the film photographs comes from the photo being slightly three dimensional.  In the black and white image, you would have a very slight coin-like relief in the silver etching your image onto the photograph; by contrast, an ink or laser printer would be a single layer.  In the color versions, I would be curious to know what the ordering of each color is - Something like GBR from bottom to top would indicate to me that the film designers were intentionally taking advantage of this three dimensional effect by stacking typical background colors below typical foreground colors (imagine a human face against a green forest).

The silver particles actually hold the image by the same chemical process that tarnishes your fine flatware.  So the negative is actual tarnish on the silver.  So, theoretically, you could take a picture on a silver spoon.

This is quite interesting. I used to work in photo lab some 20 years ago. Right before digital photography revolution. Used to develop dozens upon dozens of negatives/diapositives on a daily basis. It is weird to see these guys doing everything in the dark. We had machines where you would tape that tongue of the film to a perforated card and the machine would pull out the film, cut at the end and process the film based on your settings. No dark room needed.
We used dark rooms for other stuff, one of the most exciting moments was when I helped to expose/develop 10x6 feet photo composed of multiple sheets using enormous negative, all in a pitch black room. Also, retouching, aka analogue photoshop was lots of fun. The way you could make soft bloom using grease from your fingers, or multiply/screen parts of images. Fun times.

But I absolutely love digital cameras, I would be so sad if I had to return to analogue. It is exciting and different for someone who haven't used it for long, I can get that. I can get the hobby side too, both with film and old cameras/lenses. My first camera was legendary Russian Zenit from like 60's and I had most fun with that one. It was full manual, no battery, no light meter, no autofocus. You had to think about lots of things to take good photos with that one.

3:17 - RIP camera. Watching that I can hear my photography teacher telling us about the risk of damaging your camera in long exposures without a tripod. That and keeping the shutter open like that without a lens on is risking dust in your camera and all-over all future pictures.

You get a similar feel with a DSLR with a broken LCD panel and 1 GB memory card. The important part of the film photography is not having a method to instantly check your results. That forces you to think more about what you're doing. Even if you have configured your DSLR to not show the preview automatically, you still know that you can immediately review the photo if needed.

Taking photos of important moments without ability to know if the photo was successful and not being able to just shoot 100s of photos to make sure you have at least one successful shot makes all the difference.

Also most film SLRs come with a really high quality lens (for its time!) which is usually much better than the kit lens most people shoot with their DSLR.

I remember developing film in a dark room when I was 12 years old in junior high school (7th grade).  We also had metal shop and wood shop, where we would learn to cut, bend, weld, drill and tap metal, and cutting, planing, routing, drilling, making plugs and other interesting things, painting or varnishing wood.  I think kids need to learn more stuff like that when they're 12-13 years old.  I had to take wood shop, metal shop, electronics where we learned about diodes, resistors capacitors transformers and other electronic components, & home skills or whatever it was called where we sewed and cooked.  All those classes were required in grades 7-9 in Minnesota where I lived at the time.  I also took the optional small gas engines class, where we were each required to rebuild a lawn mower engine, where the inside of the cylinder was intentionally scored, and needed honing and oversized piston rings.  Amazing I still remember this... and I'm almost 40 now.

The old way of doing things feels more “physical” than the digital electronic way. It might be slower or less efficient but it’s more tactile and interactive, making it more enjoyable if you take the time to understand how it works. Something digital doesn’t have. Vinyl records, valve radios and amplifiers, Nixie tubes, letterpress printing, typewriters, fluorescent and sodium lighting, CRT TV, film - everything done digitally today was done mechanically or chemically only a short time ago!
It’s also important to remember these things in case they need resurrecting one day. The digital world is very ephemeral, storage only lasts for a short time before it needs transferring to the latest format. It doesn’t take much to disrupt the world’s supply of semiconductors, and the skills to make ICs are very specialised. We’ve put all our eggs in one basket with the internet and our digital lives, remember that and keep the old ways alive. They’re more fun now and might become useful again at some point!

Great video Dustin. Today, I was going through some things and I found some prints that I shot when I lived in Colorado back in the early 90s. That feeling you described about shooting with film being "special" was a reality. As I looked at the prints, it seemed like time slowed down and I was taken back to that time, to the moment I took them, not just the image, but the feeling of being there once again. Here is a short story about one of the images: I was hiking up in the Rocky Mountain National Park (near Estes Park) and I had my camera. I took several pictures. About 3 miles into my hike, I came across a nice little stream with some granite boulders in it. I only had 1 exposure left on the roll and no spares. I wanted to do a long exposure to make the water look like it was "painted" into the picture (creating motion). Usually, I would "bracket" the shot (take 3 exposures with 2 shots one setting above and below what I thought it should be and 1 shot at the settings I thought it should be) but, I only had 1 shot left on the roll. So, I set my shutter speed to a slightly longer exposure and my F stop so less light would hit the film, so the long exposure wouldn't wash out the image. It came out perfect. I was so proud of that picture... Today, people don't understand why it is such a big deal. You can just "photoshop" it or (with digital cameras) take 4 or 5 shots and pick the one you like the best, and delete the rest. It's kind of like hunting with a bow or a muzzle loader compared to a semi-automatic rifle. You only get one chance, so you need to get it right the first time. It is more about accomplishment than just taking a picture.

Thanks for the memories!  When I got out of the US Army in 1970 I went to work at Eastman Kodak in Rochester NY.  I was fortunate to work in a number of different departments over the years.  Kodak was a huge company employing 60,000 people in Rochester at one time. I worked in machine fabricating and maintenance and moved around a lot. The machines that made the film base as well as the machines to put the coatings on the base to produce the film and the machines to make photo paper were all custom made in house. They were huge. For instance a roll coating machine was 5 stories high. Kodak also made all their own chemicals, fim and slide projectors and cameras as well as x-ray film and professional and consumer film processors. Employees could also get free film of all types when it had expired, rarely did you hear of the film not working properly. Those were the days!

My first job after leaving school in 1980 was to work in one of those photography labs, working in the dark room developing and printing before digital came in being. We printed to paper directly and then ran the paper rolls back through a whole other development process.
That machine is an advanced system, we had to replenish and batch test when running through thousands of film strips a day. With colour index tests before and after each batch run.

I can still remember sitting in the dark for over an hour in a film loading room when the class project roll of B&W I had to develop wouldn't thread onto the tank spindle properly. The longer it went, the more it didn't want to thread properly.

I would have preferred a double blind test to see if there's really anything special to 35mm film. The resolution of DSLR cameras is sufficient to be functionally equivalent to film and the dynamic range of digital sensors can surpass that of film as well.

I'm not saying that there isn't a "look", but I would bet money that an AI could be developed to mimic that "look" digitally so that few could tell the difference. There's also a different look to 16mm or 75mm that isn't purely relegated to quality.

The science of how it's done certainly IS special... but so is the science of capturing images through a digital process.

0:29 To your point of shooting vast numbers of photos w/digital to 36 w/35mm: when I went to large format the film holders only have 1 sheet of film on each side of the film holder. In other words, 2 shots at a time. It was with this process that I learned to think to the darkroom. The better the negative the better the print.

Also, sheet film offers the advantage of grouping like negatives by lighting conditions. If it was a cloudy day all those negatives would be developed together, likewise for sunny, etc.. With roll film (120, 35mm) you will almost always have a mixture of lighting situations that development is designed for a “perfect” negative or positive (slide file/chromes).

Destin, If you enjoy shooting film, you might want to consider getting a medium format camera (or for the really adventurous people reading my comment, possibly even large format... though mastering that is as much a committment as making a Youtube channel into a success). I'll resist my nerdy urges get go into a bunch of technical details about the advantages of medium format... Yes, the image quality and tonality are better, but really, that's only a small part of what motivates me to shoot larger film formats. I suppose the biggest draw is that the connection to making a photograph is even more significant with medium format than it is with 35mm when compared to digital. 

In the past, the average person shot 35mm because it was more economical, somewhat easier, and more accessible than shooting a larger format, but today the expenses are pretty much the same (if not totally in favor of shooting medium format), they are pretty much equally accessible, and people who shoot film are typically the types of people willing to learn more about photographic process than the average consumer in film's heyday.

With the right knowledge in actual DCC programs like photoshop, you can easily recreate the analog feel of film. Granted, yeah, it's tedious, but you can make macros for it to speed up the process. You can also reverse engineer color lookup-tables for film brands by using a color calibration card. You meter your environment and camera settings, take a series of photos with the card using different exposures and settings, develop the photos, scan them, then use software to compare the expected color card values to what you got. From there, you can make 3d LUTs to emulate the color profile of the film+scanner, across various exposures and variables. I'm sure there are people far more knowledgeable in this topic, that can explain this process better, but as far as I know, that's how it works at a "tip of the iceberg" level.
Out of all the digital cameras, Fuji comes closest by far to recreating this 'magic'.  Having shot Canon for 30 years as a photographer, Fuji's look is the only brand that reminds me of my film days.

I have a Canon 5D Mk IV DSLR camera.  However, back in 1979 I got a Canon A1 SLR camera that I used extensively while stationed in Germany.  With the negatives that I accumulated with the Canon A1 I decided to get the Epson Perfection V850 pro scanner to scan all the negatives include people who have had the experience using 35mm negative films.  I also use the Silverfast 9 AI Studio software for processing the scans which is an excellent software.  I've seen photo prints and negatives in flea markets which I myself hunt for to see other peoples photography.

I did this back in the late 90s until the lab closed in 2001. Our printing process was entirely optical though, which had its own idiosyncrasies. For example, we would put a base color/density correction in and we'd have to wait until the prints came out of processing to make final(hopefully) corrections. When that lab closed, I got a job at a lab that used a Frontier scanner; which made the process so much easier.

Our dark room was actually two separate rooms. The film processor room on one side, and the enlarger room on the other. So we would print photos up to 16x20 in the enlarger room, and we had some other printers used for weird gauges of film (prints off 8mm, minox, larger 120 aspect ratios, etc.).
we're so proud to share our passion with the world. The art of film photography is here to stay. LONG LIVE FILM.

In school, I worked a lot in dark rooms to develop for school papers, students, etc.  And I also transitioned to digital as it emerged.  Part of what I think helps bring richness from analog film is color bleed.  In analog film, the scattering of photons on the silver layer will excite more than one silver fleck, and even refraction off that fleck will excite others.  And it is this non-binary mechanism that I believe leads to deeper saturation and swaths of smoother gradient, compared to digital imagery, where there is much more limited distribution of color change and sometimes more drastic steps of color change for each pixel on the die.

Destin, thanks for sharing your film journey with us. I can definitely relate.
I am and Engineer and I have had a film journey as well - much inherited from my dad and grandmother which spans almost 100 years and from Texas to the Moon.
The oldest camera I recall in my family is my Grandmother's Brownie 616 which I still have. After that, I have my Dad's Autographic Brownie. A really unusual bellows camera.
My Dad then was in WWII with the Air Force as a Navigator and then, in the 1940's began working with camera for reconnaissance.
After 26 years he then transitioned again to work for NASA in Apollo to develop the techniques for surveying the lunar surface using camera installed in Apollo 8.
I grew up with that and was fascinated on how much was being done with cameras and I have lots of memories of that time.
After that I got my MSEE from TAMU and worked with ICs and saw how photography was used to make integrated circuits.
After that I went to work in Implantable Medical Electronics. I had a friend who was also a photographer and worked in our marketing department and he showed me the largest camera I have ever seen. It was a box camera that was build into the dark room. You walked inside the camera to change the film. So cool.
Now I still work in Implantable Medical Electronics where I also work with robots that use vision to do alignment and detect defects. The world of photography is ever changing.

Destin. When I was in college, I took photojournalism and learned black and white developing and how it works and used it for years. I use photography mostly in forensic contexts now as a private detective and find digital far superior for that, and have a Nikon D3000 for this work. However, I am in full agreement regarding the aesthetics. My hypothesis as to why it looks better is that the crystals are randomly arranged and more closely mimic human vision, as opposed to the rows and columns of digital sensors. That being said, there is enough variation from one sensor to the next, that there is a process of being able to distinguish pictures taken by one camera from pictures taken by another, even the same model and to identify the camera that took a particular image, and I don't mean just EXIF data. There have been further advancements that allow one to establish whether a given photo has been altered and which parts are original and which parts are altered. The methods and apparatuses to do this are described in US Patents 7.616,237 B2 and 8,855,358 B2 by Fridrich, Goljan and Lukas.

Random microscopy tip from a microbiologist / microscopist. Your microscope objective lenses need a very slight adjustment to be "parfocal". Essentially amounts to adding very then plastic shim rings between the base of your threaded objective lenses and the female mount on the rotating nosepiece. When correctly adjusted your focal point is exactly the same as you rotate through all of your objective lenses, hence you don't need to to refocus after changes.

We had a film lab in high school! I took film photography around 2006, which is ironic because the school was just renovated two years before including adding the film lab, just after digital had all but replaced film. We had one of those revolving doors, and the photo processing room was very dimly lit by red lights instead of complete darkness. I don't remember much about developing the film itself, but I do remember exposing the strips of film onto a single 8x10 piece of paper to make thumbnail images just like you would see in your Windows file explorer. Then we would line up an individual frame of the negative on an enlarger (like a specialized projector) for a brief second onto photo paper, then run it through various chemicals on a central table and hang them up to dry overnight. For my class I used an old Minolta camera from my godfather who was a Hollywood photographer in the 70s.

Thank you so much for sharing with your audience the art form that I have dedicated my life to. Something about watching you discover this makes me think about all the hours I spent in dark rooms developing and printing in college and how lucky I am to know about this stuff. Thank you

Loved the video. I just don't really like the intro. I'm sure you disagree with me, because you put the intro in there, but I just want to explain why I feel the way I do. Maybe we both can learn something.

'Taking a film photo seems more meaningful.'
I think digital photos can feel equally meaningful. You just need to take your time. Sure, with film there's actual consequences of losing a quarter each time you open the shutter. But it might make it so you miss more moments.
It's like saying that typing on a typewriter feels more meaningful. Sure, you're right that some people feel that way, but the annoyance of using white out, or getting the keys jammed isn't worth it for most people. It seems like nostalgia plays a big role in people's enjoyment of film. The film photos feel like a distant memory, because it's what your earliest memories were shot on. It looks old because your old photos use film. Why is that wonderful or interesting to you? But the point more in need of justification, why does that bother me so much?

I guess I have a problem with the whole traditionalist mentality of "past good, now bad" which I'm probably overextending that dislike to trivial extremes (like your film intro).
The world today is better in so many ways- like Steven Pinker often talks about. But still, people think the past is better. Sure childhood is better than adulthood. Adult problems aren't fun. Different things aren't as fun when you're older (unless you're on acid).
But when people advocate a return to the past, like Uncle Rico, to the detriment of those who live in the present-- I just slap my head. I'm sure your (great?) grandparents thought washing clothes or dishes by hand was more meaningful. It's just a waste of water, and time that could be spent with family.
In the end everyone gets to decide what they want to do with their time. I'm wasting mine by supposing you read any comment with less than 100 upvotes. But at least I've better clarified my own feelings on the subject, and can hopefully change someone's mind down the road.

Keep it up, Dustin. Although, I would've loved a history intro instead of a weak justification for a film preference. Haha. But I assume you shot the video digitally-- so I'm probably being unfair.

I remember from about 20 years ago, before digital cameras were a thing, I took a film camera to a festival to take Pictures. I took two or three rolls of film and they all turned out terrible. It turns out, the long development cycle is a major disadvantage of film photography. If you don't know how to shoot correctly, you have to invest a huge amount of time (and money) to learn how to handle your camera.
This all has improved tremendously when digital photography became wide-spread. This is only the largest disadvantage of film photography.
I do understand that there's some nostalgia connected to obsolete technology and I do understand that it's fun to play around with unnecessary stuff - I do it all the time. But let's not deny that the old tech is gone for one major reason: it has been replaced by something better.

The color layer order in the color film graphic is reverse.
Normally silver halides are only sensitive to blue light and higher in the spectrum. This is important for color film.
Color film works like this:
1st layer is sensitive only to blue.
2nd layer filters out blue light
3rd layer is sensitive to green and above, but the blue has been filtered out.
4th layer filters out green
5th layer is sensitive to red and above, but again the other colors have been filtered out.

Developing some interesting things happen.
In color film layers there are also dyes, these dyes are "uncoupled" so they are not visible. When you put color film into color developer the silver halides with latent image become metallic silver and a side reaction happens that combine those die parts and make them visible
"Bleaching" is a name for a process of turning metallic silver back into silver halide. This is done to remove all of the silver from the film during fixing. Developed film does not have any silver left in it once it is developed. The image come from those coupled dyes.

My previous workplace was a photography store in Stockholm (Sweden). we had (they still have) two machines for the process of developing film. Our opener for getting the film out basically just made the end of the film peak out of the opening, so you didn't "pop" the housing. That way the film was always in darkness. The film then ran through a closed machine that had all the chemicals in it (just like in this video). It was on sort of a conveyer belt. When it got to the end of the roll, it snipped off the housing.

After the film passed it was safe to be in the light. We then pushed it through a small scanner (with dedicated software) that is designed for film (again very similar to the video). The pictures then got printed and the costumer could have the digital files for about $5 extra.

We also used a pretty much identical numbering system as they do in the video. It was a cool job, and I hope they get more business if film makes a comeback :)

So the big difference is that our process didn't need a dark room

Justin, The difference is value. We attach value to things that represent effort. Since the smart phone we attach very little to digital images, because they represent very little effort.

A film camera represents many more emotional choices and effort to arrive at a single exposure, resulting in attaching much greater value to a film exposure than a digital one, in most cases.

The reason I believe based on my research is that we attach emotional memories to things we value. As a portrait photographer my job is to create emotional memories for people to attach their story too. This is infinitely more complex since digital photography happened and I have had to create an enormously more complex experience to create value in my photography. But the end result is iso much more rewarding for me and my clients.

A few years ago, I was walking around trying out the Hasselblad 500 I just had gotten as a trade-in for an Olympus E3 (yeah.. that was a good deal for me..).. Anyhow, while setting up for a picture of the Dom Church in Utrecht, I was addressed by someone, asking if I was using film with it...

Initially that question surprised me, of course I was.. the next question was why... so I explained my primary motivation being to force myself to take the time for thinking about every picture I take.

The person addressing me turned out to be a well known local photographer, Sjaak Ramakers, who has been using Hasselblad cameras for a long long time, and had recently switched to using digital backs for his 500s (for studio use), and gave me a few bags of leftover film, and all the analog backs and related items.. because he liked, and could agree with my motivation.

I rarely ever use film nowadays, actually just shoot about 1 or 2 rolls of film each year now to ensure the camera keeps getting used (leaving mechanical cameras unused for too long will cause them to fail or at least require additional service), but still take a lot more time for my picures, and rarely ever use a 'spray and pray' approach unless it is really the only way to get a specific image I need for something.

I worked at walmart from 2006-2012 and they started phasing out developing 35mm in store a few years later (2009) or so? We used the fuji frontier devices. We also couldn't share photos with anyone and kept things to ourselves. The only time that it was an issue is when idiots were taking photos of a lot of drugs and we even caught a person doing shady things to some kids ... so we turned that into the police for investigation. With every developed roll of film, we provided a free digital CD along with it as well.
We also had control strips that we tested every morning before we started for the photo printer. Same concept, everything had to pass before we could start. It would fail if it wasn't within a certain range. We also had to clean the machine monthly and change out chemicals every 3 months or so if I remember right. Every 6 months we had an inspection from Fuji. They came in and checked out all the machines and made sure we were maintaining all their equipment properly. It was a pain in the butt ... lol

After my mom passed away in 2012, I turned to photography as a way to explore my world and get myself out of the house. I picked film cameras because back then they were dirt cheap and I could get a professional system for not a lot of money. Years on, I've explored 35mm, medium format in every size, large format in 4x5 and 5x7 and I am still amazed at film. I have plenty of digital cameras as well, but there is something special about developing film, and if you have the chance to print your film shots on photo sensitive paper that makes the process come alive. There is nothing quite like being in a darkroom with the red safe light on (for B&W) and seeing your print magically appear in the developing bath.

Well ... crud. I feel really ancient now, calling mid 90s digital, automated photo processing "really old"! I learned photography (I guess it was quite some time ago) using the little canister shown at the beginning of the video, and the "print" process was a second exposure on paper or other film and yet another 3 step chemical process for each individual image. Even more rewarding than just taking the picture was seeing it through the chemical processing and editing the final image. The "print" process can be done in deep red light so you can actually see, and watching the image suddenly appear on the white paper was INDEED magical.
I will also say that just because they invented nail guns, it doesn't mean your 20oz claw hammer is obsolete. There's a time , place and reason for using each one. But to tell the truth, mastering the skill to drive a 16 penny nail home, straight and true, in three whacks is far more rewarding. Sometimes, in some (deeper) ways "old" is better.

The Issues with labs today is it's a cost of scale operation i.e 35USD per roll for a 20MP scan and multiple days turn over time.

For a 150USD hit in the secondary kit and doing it yourself becomes a clear ROI by your 3rd or 5th roll and processing time can be hammered out to under 40min per roll from development to scanning corrections and putting your binder on a shelf, now I'm not bashing labs I'm just saying its more cost-effective by a huge margin if you shoot more then let's say 20-40 rolls a year especially on scanning to just buy a slide duplicator some extender rings and an older digital 35mm camera with a half-decent macro lens and with 600USD or so you have a full lab that fits in a backpack and has no secondary costs but a few 100GB of storage a year and new chemicals every 20-30 rolls and that's a setup that will last years.

(You can also rent a 61mp body like the A7RIV with its pixel shift for a yearly archival scan batch with a current-gen macro lens for less than the cost of drum scanning and only taking time)

There is a LOT more to the story of film vs digital photography. First of all. If you take photos with a large format camera, the film is quite big and the output of the camera will be like a digital camera with a 300 Mpixel resolution. You can buy a large format film camera, but today, you still can't buy a digital camera with that resolution. And if you get back to the good old 135-format (classic filmrolls) there is something strange when compairing film to digital. A photo taken on film can be enlarged a huge lot without looking bad, and when enlarging a digital photo a bit the result just looks very sad and no good at all.
A tip for your next video if continuing on the film theme. The E6 and the C41 color process (film positive aka dia vs color negative) are compatible. Hence, its possible to make color negatives out of a positive film and vice versa. Its really fun! And. Strange. By the way. Kodacrome positive film is not compatible, and the process is as far as I know still secret and the last kodacrome positives where developed in 2008.
Another fun story: I cleaned out a garage in 2010, found a black and white film roll, undeveloped. Realized that that Ilford film type was last made in 1986 and probably spent its days in room temperature and in a drawer. Tried out to develop this 25 years (or more!) old film, added some possassium bromide to the developer, and YES it worked, got a lot of good pictures out of a film that had been just laying for decades. Amazing!

I used to do black and white film photography. I enjoyed developing my own film and photos.

I got my first SLR film camera in the mid 60s. Nothing about it was automatic, so I had to learn about f stops and exposure time along with the trade offs between film speed vs grain in the final image. I shot mostly in black and white because I could develop and print photos at home and the film was cheap. The learning curve to produce great photos with film and develop prints is fairly steep. Shoot the photos, develop them and then print. You don't get a second chance if you make a mistake. Consequently, you take more time to adjust the camera settings, compose the shot and press the shutter. It's both exciting and terrifying to pull the developed film from the can, especially if the photos are of a once in a lifetime event. After awhile, all of the technical details become second nature and you concentrate on making the best composition. If I hadn't learned all that techy stuff, I don't think I would be making great photos with my digital SLR.

If you want the experience of shooting with film on a digital camera, try this. First, if you have a DSLR, put it in manual mode. See what happens with various f stop, exposure time settings, and ISO settings. Limit yourself to taking just 36 or 24 exposures, as you would with film. Finally, don't even think about looking at the preview of the pictures as you take them. Wait a few days before loading the photos onto your computer. Chances are you won't have many "keepers" unless you already have a good feel for the technical side of photography. Look at the metadata stored with each image to see what the camera settings were. They hold the clues to why a photo turned out great or was a dud. If you keep practicing, you'll gain a much better understanding of how to set the camera and compose a photo to get extreme focus for some situations or a soft blurred background for others. You'll get a feeling for how light works with shadows and how to capture skies without blowing out the highlights. You will find that you actually have more "keepers" while taking fewer photographs.

Smartphones and digital cameras are great, but their highly automated modes leave little more to the user than to push a button.

Regardless of if film or digital gives a better picture (I believe digital can give a better picture in theory, and that it's already equivalent quality wise with film) the thing is the quality isn't really what's important, at least not for things you're taking pictures of with film. Film just has a particular experience to it. I've never actually used a film camera (or if I did, I was very little when I did), but I do like the idea of them. Though if I could only pick one camera I'd go with a digital camera (though I'm not a photographer). But older technologies are just nice in their own ways. Even with computers, there's just something special about retro computers; you were more involved in the system (it's also why I like manual transmission in cars; it's nice to feel like you're part of the system, rather than being outside the system, if that makes sense).

Have you seen how pictures used to be developed? I did photography in high school and we had a retro setup with 8 enlargers and two dark rooms (dark dark for negatives and red dark for photo paper). We used the hand crank machine you showed at the beginning for our negatives. It took practice to open a film canister and load it in the machine with nothing but feeling and hearing! I really miss developing my own photos. Getting that solarized effect where the whites go black and the blacks go silver, is so satisfying. Doing different exposure techniques, getting to edit photos by hand with nothing more than an enlarger and a few mediums, it's such a satisfying experience. Editing on a computer yields amazing photos. But there's just something about doing it with your own hands.

It used to be a physical process where all our still used terminology like masking, burning, blending etc. come from. Please also go to a lab where they create actual prints, especially from black and white negatives to an actual very high resolution print.

My favourite kind of flim was diapositive, where after exposure and developing you actually have a film with positive frames (like in a movie). These are then cut out and framed in little plastic frames, which can be viewed on a big silver screen using a projector. And of course there is an analog process to convert that to print (possibly via an actual negative, but I'm not sure).

I have worked for 24 years in film and paper Photo Lab. Micro crystals of halogen silver ( Black and white) or Chromium and some silver Halogens ( Color) are much finer than size of pixels therefore Digital is not yet as fine as Film is. Various Black and White processes, C-41, E2, EP2, E6, RA4 are some of film / paper photo processes. There are also others like Micofilms, Infrareds, half tones and so on.
Your Dip and Dunk Refrema processor is for bulk volume of film. a Single roll of film can be processed manually. there are also stack hand processing tanks for up to 5 rolls of film.

Now that Destin has fallen in love with film, next he will probably find the vinyl. But on the matter of film, what is it about the magic of the movie, or "the movie magic"? The magical number of 24 that creates a movie as we love it, number that compared to today feels so small and still almost every movie released uses it while mindboggling amount of video is released every day with numbers 30, 60 or even 1 000 000.
And yes, I mean frames per second. Today 30 and 60 FPS are the norm everywhere except in movies and TV series where the norm is 24 FPS. 24 FPS that is the minimum to trick human into perceiving motion as constant (with a just a touch of motion blur and human will perceive motion as smooth) while it is far from constant. But if you make a movie with 48 FPS or 60 FPS, humans perceive the movie lacking something or as "odd" while the movie should have just more constant motion and less need for motion blur making the image sharper, we even edit movies that were released with high frame rates into 24 FPS format for other releases because "movie magic". What happens at 24 FPS that makes the movie feel movie? Is it that we need to process the footage we see and something in us says it is wrong but we cannot put our mind to really think about it? Or is it just that we are accustomed to see movies at 24 FPS and we have hard time recognizing anything else as a movie footage? Would a YT video be different with some "movie magic" or would it feel as fiction just because that "movie magic"?

Destin talking like a romantic about film photography nips at my classical sensibilities.  It's not that I'm against film.  I enjoy film.  But digital photography is objectively better.  The finest grain films are roughly equal to a 21 MP sensor, and it takes a skilled photographer with quality equipment to achieve that.  Amateurs with a moderate digital setup can capture photos that rival the best film photos from a few decades back, load them onto a computer in a few minutes, then manipulate them to their heart's content.  As for the supposed difference in the finished product, it would take a well trained eye to distinguish between a film exposure and a digital photo until the image is enlarged enough to display just how much greater the resolution is from the digital photo.

Destin, WAY back in 1976 at the tender age of 16 I got a job creating microfiche. Specifically, Computer Output Microfiche, or COM. 105 mm film that had, if I recall correctly, a speed of 5. Highly saturated in silver to be able to see reports reduced by as much as 72 times (though 42x and 48x was more common.) The film was so full of silver that the off cuts at the beginning and end of each production run were saved, and then eventually sold to recycling companies that would chemically removed the silver from the film and do so profitably. If you look at historical silver pricing, you will find a huge spike in November of 1979. The Hunt brothers had come up with a scheme to try to "corner the market" on silver, and I remember the owners of the company I worked for literally fearing that they were going to go bankrupt, because we had fixed price contracts with our customers, but the price of film went up drastically. The scheme ultimately failed. I ended up working part time during college at a COM company in San Antonio. The branch manager was kind of amazed that an 18 year old kid could answer all his questions about D-Max/D-Min, order of the chemicals in the processor, and already knew how to both operate and program the COM recorders.

For Anyone that wants the closest film experience on a digital camera, get yourself a fuji X series(used xt2 can be found for 400 USD) and get some manual lenses.

Vintage canon fd, helios, pentax, Olympus, vivitar, Konika, Nikon, Industar, Jupiter, Plenty of options sub 100 USD including adapters, or try new models like TTartisas, pergear, 7artisans, Meike, Neweer, Voking, Yongnuo or Mitakon to Name a Few.

Fuji x cameras have mostly analog-style dials and with film simulation, recipes, and manual lenses, you find yourself taking your time on each shot!

Also, manual lenses are budget-friendly compared to their electronic counterparts, For example, a mint condition canon FD 72-210 zoom with macro ring, can be found at 25 USD!

I recommend the TTartisan 50mm F1.2(around 115 USD) or Pergear 25mm F1.8(around 65 USD) as your first lenses.

If you mean it seriously with photography and develop all your RAWs afterwards in LightRoom/ CaptureOne, then you have the similar rewarding feeling with digital cameras as with old analog film cameras. You don't want to have too many photos because selecting, developing, manipulating and converting them afterwards costs a lot of time. So after a while you shoot much more conciously and concentrate on making the perfect shot and taking as few photos as possible to reduce the workload afterwards. And then it's the same rewarding feeling when the pictures are developed and converted and you see them in their full glory for the first time (with a nice before and after effect). So I don't see any advantage of analog cameras here.

The look ("feeling") of the pictures is also no real reason for an analog camera. You CAN recreate that perfectly and easily with filters (if you like the look). Not with a crappy iPhone but easily with professional RAW converters like CaptureOne, Lightroom etc.

And no, analog film cameras are not "coming back". Sure, maybe the demand increased a bit, but they will always stay in a niche, like old record players. That's for some enthusiasts in a niche, but not interesting for the mass market at all. For good reasons.

I grew up shooting, developing and printing B&W Film in my Dad's darkroom. Spent many years doing it as part of my first job after High School. Then Digital took over, although I never really enjoyed it much. I decided to go back to shooting film full time about 5 years ago and I am once again shooting, developing and printing my own B&W Film in my own little darkroom. What a true joy it has been to once again see my images come to life in the tray. I am so glad that film is making a come back with a new generation of photographers.

One of the most important aspects of the "film look" might come down to the dynamic range, the way it preserves / compresses highlights not clips them like digital. Weird it wasn't mentioned. Same with analog audio, tube warmth, tape saturation etc. The smooth, pleasant non-linear distortion instead of harsh clipping. That being said, I still enjoy digital audio, video and photography more unless an analog version is the only available or really mastered better. Some laserdiscs are better than their DVD counterparts. Some CDs are overcompressed/limited etc (loudness war).

Guys, after developing my own B&W for years it was really wonderful to see your lab. Very educative for the younger up and coming photographers who only know digital technology.

By the way 2/3 of the digital sensor image is actually a "fake image" calculated by the processor. This is due to RGB layer of a sensor having different pixel for each color. So colors are actually "made up" in digital images. There is no real representation of the scene, as what you would get from film when the actual light burns it.  Of course it is fairly accurate calculations, but it brings that plastic, unnatural, clean look. While the film always looks dreamy and almost alive in some sense.

"[N]o amount of digital manipulation or Instragram filters can recreate that feeling that film just gives you straight out of the camera." Steve Yedlin would beg to differ; his work on reproducing the qualities of film in a digital environment are fascinating and state-of-the-art. You do have a point, though, in that this process is by no means easy. It's very specialized and requires advanced everything, from knowing the exact properties of both the digital camera you're using and the film camera you're trying to mimic, to programming your own color-correction software to alter the full 3-d color gamut in ways that even Photoshop can't yet do. I highly recommend anyone who's interested to have a look at his writings and videos on the topic.

Don't get me wrong, film certainly does have an organic look that can be aesthetically pleasing right out of the box, but the idea that digital can't match that is nothing but a myth at this point. Not only can the best digital sensors capture as much (if not more ) dynamic range and resolution, but even the color science of a particular film stock can be emulated very convincingly.

I have a ton of respect for Dustin, but it made me cringe when he said "no amount of digital manipulation or Instagram filters can recreate that feeling." Obviously Instagram filters can't, but as far as digital manipulation, that certainly can. While the various characteristics that produce "the film look" may seem like magic, they're not. This is science, just like anything else, and once you understand why an image on film looks the way it does, you can take a digital image (preferably shot RAW) that was captured by a camera with sufficient dynamic range, resolution, and color depth, and emulate those characteristics.
That's why I have a V330 scanner at home:)

I'm 36. I've been shooting, and still shooting film since I was 10. I'm not a hipster, nor an elitist. I don't think film has better quality than digital. I also don't think film does something that digital photos can't. I don't necessarily think there are any big advantages to shooting film as oppose to shooting digital. But I shoot film because its just a special experience.

I could catch a red eye flight from LA to NY and sleep. But you can also spend the extra time to drive and appreciate the journey of getting there. Both offer the same result, but I would compare shooting film to the road trip. You don't need to hand make something you can just injection mold. You don't need to bike when you can drive. You don't need to drive when you can fly.

But each method offers vastly different experiences. I love film photography because I appreciate the result, but also appreciate the process. I'm glad film is getting a second life these days. I love that people are rediscovering film and its unique charm. Thank you Destin, I've been a long long fan.

Hey Destin! Thank you so much for making this video! The joy you exude is a breath of fresh air. I took a semester of traditional darkroom photography in college and immediately fell in love! I learned how to do the process entirely by hand from rolling, shooting, and developing film to working with enlargers in the darkroom to manually moving the photopaper through the developer, stopper, fixer, and rinse baths. Everything I did was in monochrome which I absolutely love the look and feel of! It's my favorite type of film by far.
I love nothing more than taking a photo of my friends and knowing that from start to finish, I did every little step! Handing them a print that I made (and they modeled for) is such a wonderful feeling. The process, results, and amount of control is something that digital can never touch. Isn't it odd how with modern software you can be so exact and calculated with the entire photography process but working with film and chemicals by hand yields the best and most precise results? My dream is to have my own darkroom in my house because I really love developing the film and prints myself manually, but until then I've been shooting polaroid so I can still get the feeling of working in film.
Watching this video was so fun! You did an excellent job highlighting the process and it definitely made me laugh when you were so interested in the mechanical operation of the film developing machine! I love all your videos but this one is especially fascinating to me. I now feel the desire to get out my dad's old 35mm film camera that I first learned on. Thanks again!

P.S. If you enjoyed learning about the chemical process behind color film, check out the chemical engineering behind making instant film like polaroid. Some of the most complex chemical reactions you'll be around! Super interesting stuff how they combine the entire photography process into one batch of chemicals stored on the photopaper itself, it's the film, final picture, and chemicals all together!

I saw this video, and immediately wondered how the subject would be approached. I went to photography school when cameras were all, pure mechanical machines. you adjusted the shutter speed, the aperture, the asa/iso( the sensitivity of the film to light)(and if the camera did not have a light meter, then you went and bought one, or , from experience, knew how to adjust the camera settings to the light conditions. I bought my first camera while in the service, it was a Nikon F1 in 1970 for $250.00. the Nikon F6, there latest(mechanical camera) now costs $6500.00. I own an F5, and if there are any Nikon owners reading this they will attest to  the fact that these cameras are built like tanks; they are designed to be USED. I have literally ran miles of film through this camera, and like the Timex commercial, "takes a licking, and keep on ticking". Why is film different? If you have to place a negative under a microscope, you immediately understand. there is literally millions of light sensitive, light adsorbing "microscopic" particles side by side, on top of each other, overlapping each other; whereas a digital camera has round, discrete sensors parked beside each other, thus inherently creating gaps in the image. And what used to be called grain, is now called noise. And grain was magic when used properly in black and white film processing, and printing. And in the video, the nitrogen(bursts) in the lab is used to agitate the chemicals from "resting" on a piece of film, otherwise uneven development. The one other thing not directly pointed out is the precise temperature control of the chemicals, sometimes a 1 degree variation will cause a shift in the colors, where as b/w normally is processed between 68 to 72, and you could push and pull film development(the zone system Ansel Adams stuff)(usually employed on large format, view camera platforms). Lastly, shooting with film, and shooting with a mechanical camera will make you a better "image" maker. It will slow you down; it will make you evaluate the scene, and will allow you to embark on a decision that will determine the final image, and not the camera's P setting. Thank you for making this video. It was a trip down memory lane, regarding the lab, and got me excited that dinosaurs(film) still roam the earth. Maybe it is time to run a few more miles of film through my F5, now that I know where to go. I liked the owner. He definitely got his act together regarding quality control. thanks again.

The reason why I love film photography is that you have to really know what you're doing. I got a pinhole camera in 2016 and I really love that process. In order to to get a photo I have to have the shutter open for a very specific time. I love to take long exposures, I set up the camera on a table in a restaurant or on a ledge in a room and leave it open. It's like all the moments that happened during the time the shutter was open is not one single image. My favorite thing to do with a pinhole is to either hold in my hands while sitting in a car or set it up in a car and let all the lights of the cars and traffic lights be recorded on one image. To use the pinhole one must be calm and still. I did a lot of pinhole shots over the pandemic and the shots were comprised of when I was calm. I have so many rolls I need to develop

And the tanks need more chemistry. Get a Hewes, practice with a dummy roll, and pass it down generations, as they never need replacing unlike the plastic ones.

You missed one thing: when you take a photo with a film camera, the moment you press that button, you get the feeling that you've created something. That doesn't happen with a digital camera, because you can immediately check the preview screen and see what you actually got. But with film, even though the image is still 'latent,' and even though a number of things could go wrong in the processing, and the picture you took might never be seen, you nonetheless have a definite feeling that you created something. And that image exists in your mind, until you get the film developed, and find out how near or how far the image really is from the photo you thought you took. And guess what? The more time you spend learning to use your camera, the closer the images really are to what you thought you created. In time, you get to the point where you press the button, and you know what you got. With experience, you really get that feeling of creation, at the press of a button. You don't get that with digital.
