I worked in a overnight film processing lab from 2001-2011 running continuous film processors as well as Frontier minilabs. Far more automated than what you see here. We dropped rolls of film into a machine that opened the film rolls and spliced them together automatically with heat tape that served as a barcoded twin check that was also printed on the customers envelope. The film was taken up on reels which we then inspected, sometimes by hand, in the darkroom and loaded onto magazines that went onto the film processor. The machines ran continuously with the loading and unloading of the reels at the front of the machines. If the film broke at all we had to shut off the lights, close the door, and get the film moving out of the developer into a stop bath tank in less than 30 seconds otherwise the film would start to get noticeably over-developed. We'd find the break and re-splice it together and start the machine moving again.

I had completely forgotten about the control strips even though I must've spliced hundreds into reels of film! As I recall we had a machine on site that read the control strips for us so we didn't have to send those out. After working there for 10 years I can confirm that those revolving darkroom doors do not get old!

If you wanna have some fun with black and white film, look up Caffenol developer! You can use instant coffee to develop your B&W film.

Edit: Interesting details not mentioned:
Development is a chain reaction process: the light develops little seed grains of metallic silver and the development builds up larger. This means that film can be pushed and given more development for a darker negative at the cost of larger individual grains, or pulled and given less development for smaller individual grains and a lighter rendition of the same latent image.
Stand development is a weird and interesting physical process of it's own.
So is variable-contrast paper processes.
Also EVERYBODY is scared of doing C41 and E-6 by hand. The processes were designed for machine development with precise control of time and temperatures.

Scanned a lot of film in my time, and those scanners are mid-level. Not all film is high quality enough to deserve a drum scan, but drum scanners (like film vs digital) really take the quality to the next level. They use PMTs to get any resolution you like, and really capture the film grain. Even if you lower the resolution at a later step, they look much better. The only problem is that they don't have an infrared scan, which is an extra colour channel that tells you where all dirt and scratches are (and so automatically removes them from you like the photoshop heal tool). I've always thought wet scans in general look much better than dry scans, and scanning film in the curved state looks better than flat (because you never get it perfectly flat).

I worked as a lab tech at a one hour photo lab in the mid 2000s, right before they all disappeared. Thanks for the trip down memory lane! I can still remember the hand movements to scan and adjust film on a Fuji Frontier console. The specialized keyboard makes color corrections so fast, no software can match that. An experienced tech can rip through a roll of film in less than a minute. I scanned so many slides on that machine. It could have been the operators fault, but I could never get perfect colors on that scanner from Velvia slides.

The minilab film developer and printer were really cool machines. They pulled the film/paper through rollers through each chemical at a constant speed. The time in each tank was determined by the depth of the tank. Each week we had to pull each rack out of the tanks and clean them to keep them from accumulating crystals and other debris that would scratch film.

We had the pinnacle of Fuji printers, the Frontier 570. IIRC, it could print a 4x6 in about one minute, and 36 prints (one roll) in about two minutes total. If we had nothing else pending, we could develop and print a roll in under 15 minutes. That thing was a beast (temperamental, too).

We ran control strips every morning and had a color measuring machine to analyze them. We didn’t start printing if the numbers were out of range, and if they weren’t it could require draining the tanks from the machines and refilling the chemistry. Probably a two hour process.

The smell of film chemistry is so engrained in my brain, anytime I smell it I’m instantly back in the lab, or the high school darkroom.

The reason film feels "more real" is the same reason DAT tapes and vinyl sound different than WAV files. Nature is not digital. She's an analog girl, and though logically, it shouldn't make a difference with today's digital resolution, somehow it still does.

I can listen to a digital recording, made side by side of the same performance, same room, same mics, and always pull out the analog version. Not by listening to which one sounds "cleaner/better", but by listening to which one has more "space/depth". Nature goes infinitely up and down in scale, and the digital captures, wether film, music, pictures, etc... are never fully "there" against the other. If it's not a pure natural wave form, but millions of bits/pieces of said wave form, it never quite captures the entire feeling.

It's a holographic/analog universe out there. It's a shame most bands have missed this idea. Everyone plays to a perfect digital click track (not everyone, but %99). Then they edit out every slip, every mistake, every drag and jump. Everything becomes robotic. It actually all takes on a similar feel. A lifeless feel. It still sounds good, it's still music, don't get me wrong, but this was not done prior to 1995, and you can hear it. The character, the multiple takes, the mistakes still left after trying to play something difficult 1000 times, and not quite getting there, but getting close enough. The young generation, and future generations may never experience the realness of said music. Anyways, Pure art is still out there... Enjoy it while you can.

They are only IR googles, not true night vision like the military uses. The real ones actually amplify ambient light with phosphorous tubes, and the IR emitting lights that are on them are seldom used because ANYONE with IR receiver sees you like a "HERE I AM!" neon sign. So it is not really used that much in real operations. Though on moonless nights in the desert they are not that good because there is little ambient light to amplify. Though newer ones can be used better under starlight than the old ones.

Kind of surprising. No objective comparisons...digital to film... at all.

As an old person I remember my grandmother taking 2"x2" B&W photos with a little Kodak box camera...first sending the whole camera in for processing. Since then I have gone through nearly all the technologies...various Kodak color types; early cheap Sears film that couldn't hold color; various kinds of color cameras ending with the SLRs; various lens types and mounts; different sensitivities (the faster the film the grainier...B&W much faster and less grainy than color); adjusting shutter speed and aperture for depth of field... and then digital with more and more pixel resolution.

There was an epoch when all the pro photographers who would never leave film all left it. I'm convinced it was a resolution issue. Digital resolution caught up with and exceeded film resolution; digital sensitivity caught up and exceeded film sensitivity; digital color caught up and exceeded film definition; and cameras began to fire off 10 shots in a burst so you didn't get things like eyes shut or camera steadiness issues.

And yet in watching this, everything was subjective. I at least expected to see the objective measure of film grain vs pixels.

As an old person, digital music and digital photography are superior without question. Tubes are not as good as transistors. Analog equalization is not as good as DSP.

Yet in all these years, there's something about human nature that aging hasn't yet allowed me to grasp. In the end, I've found the greatest artists are the greatest story tellers...and the mushier, more subjective terms they use, the more successful they are. It's all about feeling. I never understood why we took art appreciation and music appreciation classes in elementary school...and I still don't.

They didn't make us take basketball and football appreciation classes.

Interesting thing for when you are looking at your negatives and wanting to see if it's worth putting it onto a print. You can reflect light off a black and white negative, so that you see a positive image. The dark sections reflect the light, o you see them as ... well light... and the light sections allow more light to pass through, so you see them as low light... or dark. Just hold a negative so that light reflects off it ... not through it. ie put a reading lamp over your shoulder and look at your negative. It also works with colour, but not as well.

I worked in a film lab in the mid 80s, developing C4 Slide film and doing copy standing. This brings back some fond memories. It was the first job that I had that was not in the fast food industry. There were a few times that I partially fell asleep in the dark room, while racking film. Never wrecked a roll. We had a night scope with a tight rubber cup, that we could use to find things (film rolls) that we might have dropped in the dark, but cannot turn the lights on to find.
We also had some really strict rules regarding photos that involved any nudity (and there was a lot of it) because under the law, any "contact" in the photos, required us to contact the police and hold the film until they could send someone over to inspect the photos and determine if any further investigation would take place.
So different from current day photography.

With all the film explanation that you gave, you left out one of the most common fears of film photographers; Accidentally exposed film.  When I worked in electronics department at K-mart I sold several inexpensive 35mm cameras.  One selling point of a few Fuji cameras (when electronic functions had become more common) was that when film was loaded into the camera and the back closed, the entire roll was unloaded from the canister onto the camera spool.  This allowed the lens exposed film to be drawn back into the canister shot by shot, thus preserving the shots from accidental exposure.  I also enjoyed seeing many people picking up their pictures (developed by a third party company) and instantly go through them to re-live some past moment.
It's like hunting with an AR-10 with a 20 round magazine and a couple more on your belt, vs hunting with a single shot rifle.

@26:15 "So one of our artists, Ryan Meerhan...was saying...it's really strange to me that you guys see all of my artwork literally days before I see any of it." This principal extends to other imaging fields, and with profoundly greater human reactions. As it happens, I know very well a person working on the NirCAM system for JWST, and something that is a big deal in astronomy is the human discomfort among the research scientists who are scheduling time with the JWST, and the fact that the science team that has done the design, development and testing of the instrument will be operating the system and seeing and handling the data well before the researchers get it. The NirCAM science team is, in fact, playing a similar function to what Sarah is doing here. They are validating the data and ensuring that NirCAm did the right work in data gathering before they hand over the data to the researchers. This means that the researchers have trustworthy data free of instrument artifiacts that could alter their studies and findings. But holy heck does that delay bother the researchers. They are totally uncomfortable with it. It's as if the NirCAM scientists are primed to scoop the discoveries of the researchers, and in the competitive world of scientific publications, this is a crucial thing.

About 35 years ago I occasionally worked at 1 hour photo service at the local mall where they had a FujiFilm Minilab film processor and printer. We used a special tool to remove the film leader from the canister, cut it off and then glued them on a plastic leader card that pulled two films through the baths side by side. For certain type of films we used a dark glove box to remove the film from the cassette and put it in a canister, all while keeping it in the dark, no dark room required.


During the printing we could also do certain corrections, mostly for lightness/darkness, but those were all based on looking at the negative, this was completely non-digital. The film processor and printer operated pretty much automatic though, when chemicals needed to be replaced the machine would tell you what to do, barely any knowledge or experience was necessary to operate these machines, and the quality of the photos was pretty good. I don't know how it would compare to Refrema though.



When we handled film after developing we were always wearing white gloves, so I was kind of surprised that at Indie Film Lab they handle film with their bare hands!

If not, i have to learn, but if it's fine, everything was my doing, my decisions. Not some software in some device that made some decisions for me. My own work. That is very rewarding.
And one thing to mention: Film lasts. If my grand grand kids will find my films one day, they will see the pictures. Not with an SD card .....

Love your videos, I almost skipped this one because "I know how film works". Wow, did that bring back memories. In the late 70s I worked for National Color Labs before any digital processes. There were no lights to accidently turn on in the color film/paper processing rooms, wall panels had to be removed to bring in lights. The machines were run and maintained by visually impaired workers. Chemicals were mixed on the second floor in large tanks and gravity feed to the machines. Prints were color corrected on the fly while looking at the projected negatives. Yes, it was an honor to be trusted with processing the work of some outstanding artists.

The way we used to develop film back in day at home was by using a dark bag, which looks like a shirt with no neck just sleves that closes with two zippers. The bag was made with a sort of "rubebrized" fabric on several layers that lets no light go thru... So you put the film magazines, tools and developing tank or tanks inside close the bag, put your arms in the sleves that are tight to your arms so no light will go into the bag and pop open the magazines carefully threat the film into the spirals that go into the tanks. Once the thanks is closed. You can pour the different chemicals without having any light gone into it becuse of the design of tanks. Man I use to do that very often at home specially for blach and white, but I also did it for color slides which is a special film that will give a direct possitive imagen instead of negative.

Hey man... You have no idea how nostalgic this made me. I started working in a lab when I was 13 in 1980. I started as the dip and dunk guy. I spent literally half my life in the dark. By the time I was 16, photographers were sending me their films from all over the country because I had an eye for printing (a Durst 501) which was the very rough draft of the Frontier colour correction system but no digital involved. I've worked on Frontiers but later in life around 2002 in a super automated Agfa lab. This machine could scan and print direct, but also send digital files to my workstation where I did specialized stuff on Photoshop for select clients. I've done tons of B&W darkroom work, worked with ancient as well as state of the art equipment. If I look at a negative still today, I see the image as if it is positive. My brain just makes an adjustment somehow lol. My daughter now has my old film cameras but it's hard to find film or guys processing anymore around these parts. Seeing that dip and dunk machine just brought back the smells, the sound of that mechanism, the nitrogen bubbles the awesome total darkness, even the weird slippery feel of the developer and the smell of each mixing part. Thanks for this episode.. 5 stars buddy. Oh and by the way, my only tool at the dip and dunk was a pair of scissors in my back pocket.

He was in the group that x-rayed welds looking for flaws in up=to 6 inch thick steel welded together.  They used x-ray film and had large developers and they also used to collect the silver from the solution for selling back to recover some expense.  They would use radioactive Isotopes to expose the welds..

We're realising more and more today that colour is important in the digital world.  We add shaders to digitally created images to give them that extra oomf, we add a slightly translucent colour over images to view text more easily, we realise "pure" colours on a computer are not true forms of the colour, and many people struggle with certain colours (which is why you don't often see pure forms of it).  Many people are now realising this should be a standard practice, to understand the look and the feel of something, not just the functionality of it.  And I must say, there is no recreating a film photo with digital means, but by the way it's going there soon might be, which honestly scares me (a student in their 20's) a little.

I dabbled with slide film for a while when living in a remote coal-mining town. The local pharmacy, as with most towns in Australia, was where you'd take your exposed film. They'd send it off to the Kodak labs and it would, in the case of slide film, come back in about a month or so. Regular prints would usually get back in a week or two. The anticipation when opening a box of slides, or pack of prints is something you never forget. And as you said, when we use/d film, we took time to compose our shots because with only between 12 and 36 shots to a roll, you had to try harder. While I like film - it's what I learned the fundamentals of photography on, and I've developed my own negatives and prints - I find it a little uncouth for a science channel to be talking about it like it's magical or as if it has some intrinsic properties that make it better than digital.  Film is simply one set of materials with a specific workflow.  Unless you're talking about someone taking lazy snapshots on a tight budget, the notion that you had to capture everything just right in-camera is false.  Good film photographers don't go out in the field with a single roll of film and try to perfectly capture the subject in a single shot, they make educated decisions about lighting conditions and get multiple exposures for coverage, then put in even more work in development.  Ansel Adams is about as famous a film photographer as you can get, and his calling card was extensive darkroom manipulation.

For those old enough to remember there was the same feeling in the audio world when we moved away from valve amplifiers to transistor ones, valves amps had a certain warmth and richness to the sound which you just didn't get with transistor ones.

There was an even bigger more noticeable feeling when we went from vinyl records to CD's especially on the 1st generation players. Later ones had multi oversampling techniques and the CD sound while crisp, hiss and pop free (compared to vinyl) had a very clinically clean sound that a lot of people didn't like. It is still hard to beat the physical action of removing a record from its sleeve placing it on the turntable, lifting the arm into place and settling back to listen while browsing the album cover art, lyrics etc. it's a more gentle, deliberate action compared to the throwaway media we get these days.

Like your 35mm film there's a resurgence of interest from a new young generation in turntables and analog vinyl sound, what goes around comes around (there's a pun in there somewhere I'm sure :) )

I have a theory about love and romanticism for film photography, and it's based on my experience. It seems that with film, we remember the moment that we took an image because we have limited 'rounds', as you said, but also, we have to wait an amount of time before we see our results. This helps to embed that memory and gives us a real sense of achievement when we see that our shots were successful. Whereas with digital, we shoot, we look, we keep or delete...or as with me, upload EVERYTHING to the computer and oft times forget to delete less than ideal images. It's much like today's throw-away society.

As someone who worked in the Walgreens photo lab for 4 years this is very interesting. Mostly because their tech is actually older than what I worked with (2010-ish). We did use Noritsu equipment but our development unit was self contained and could auto extract the film rolls, develop the film, dry it and put it back into the roll it came out of. It did only do at most 2 at a time though so throughput would be a lot less than this unit. Also we didn't have a fancy dark room, if the film jammed in the cartridge we'd have a black box that you'd put the film and a replacement cartridge inside. You'd then break the stuck cartridge, extract the film and attach it to the replacement unit which could be opened up to hook the film inside then closed and spun to roll it up neat. Still very interesting to see a video on this topic, adjusting the chemistry was fully automatic on ours and only needed tweaking when the control strips showed us drifting, but our was pretty simple by comparison to their setup with external replenishment.

Fun fact. Your Canon is moving your film in the wrong direction. It is much more safe, to buy a camera that first pulls the entire film out of the container. After each exposure, your valuable memories are moved back towards the container. There was a flimsy tiny film standard, working that way. Worthless. But a great cassette system.They should have developed that for 35mm. Or 70 or 80mm. Even better. Just my angry opinion.

The belief in what you see on the film is really what was there is a little short sighted (tehe). Though, honestly. How the image looks on the negative and on the final print is completely up to those who make the film and/or the final print. Modern colour photos are very much altered from the reality during production. It's an illusion. Terry Pratchett had it right.
Plus, it's environmentally wasteful.
If you look at the raw images captured by a good DLSR, you will kinda see more of what is there without the pyscho-visual adaptions done by the film producer/developer or the digital camera processing into JPEG. An undeniable fact is that the camera has no concept of white balance, this has to be added later by the developer... or done in camera today for JPEG.
The short of it is that it's all fake, it's just what method they use to match your eye's own trickery and world model.

Silver based photography IS magic. Starting from a specific event as a kid, I eventually earned a science degree and made my first career in photography. I was never any good with a camera, but spent 20 years as the head of the technical department in a large professional lab. Aside from college, I have been trained by, and worked closely with, Eastman Kodak, Fuji, Fuji- Hunt, Bremson Data, Lucht Engineering, Pako, Kreonite, and many more. Photographic labs are much more complex and precise than most people understand. It is not just chemistry, it's mechanical, pneumatic, electrical, electronic, plumbing, computers, temperature control, effluent processing, and much, much, much more, in addition to the business aspect. Everything had to be very precise. There are very narrow parameters for everything from temperature control to replenishment of the chemistry to even seemingly little things like the nitrogen gas burst agitation. Precision testing with control strips and charting the results were a huge deal to keep us on track. We used a Macbeth transmission/reflection densitometer to read all the control strips. That thing sat prominently on my desk my whole career. I was "married" to "Shirley" for decades, although "Shirley" may not be around anymore, that was more of the printing side, although that, in some form, may still be used to calibrate their monitors and scanners.
Going thru college, I was always amazed how much science there is in the photographic process and amazed how my (old school) SCUBA lessons and even astronomy lessons fit in. It is all science - it all interrelates.
I still have all my darkroom and camera gear, a deep freezer full of film, paper, and chemistry. Some day I might just set all that stuff up and show my kids "real" photography. You should try some B&W printing sometime. Watching an image form on a sheet of paper is still facinating - and magical. Yeah, I am one with "fixer in my blood".
Great show, thanks.
One memory: I purchased a night vision headset for one of our film processors to evaluate. She was a black lady who was larger than life and everyone loved her, and her big Afro, dearly. She came out of the back of the film room one day complaining she smelled smoke, still wearing the headset, trailing a plume of smoke. The smoke she smelled was the battery pack igniting her hair. End of test - start of Michael Jackson jokes.

I took a photography course in college. it was very in depth and fun. I agree with the film photo feeling. Not only did we develop by hand but also printed all in the dark room.

not that it really matters, but i think you just have a nostalgic bias friend. think about it, if you did an experiment and had a friend show you randomized photos both digital and film-based. I bet you would not be able to distinguish between them at all.

i think it's a bit wistful nostalgia overemphasising the "hands-on" experience of developing film photos. they "feel" different because of the delays, the chemicals required, the lesser room for error, the increased need for specialist knowledge, etc...

but digital photography has basically blasted photography into a mainstream hobby. back in the 80s/90s, you really needed to be quite dedicated to own a film camera and take your own photos. amateurs tend to go with disposable cameras (yikes for environment) or polaroids. today, anyone with a phone can take photos. you don't have to be good or have some finances set aside for it. you don't even really need to know much about f-stops or ISOs, but if you ever wanted to get slightly better with controlling light and stuff, that info is a few clicks away.

the digital process has granted photography a level of accessibility that rivals how the invention of the printing press did for books.

i understand that in doing coverage of the chemical process one would wanna stick to the cool parts, but the chemicals involved are actually dangerous as well. even the home-use kit is extremely flammable, and inhalation of the chemicals over a long period can be pretty detrimental to health. there are no such downsides to the digital process. an amateur can spend however long they want/need to fiddle around with photoshop until they learn/figure things out at fairly low cost. a serious film developer would need to apprentice at a lab or something to really get a feel for things -- and even then, any mistake could instantly destroy quite a lot of work.

let's also not forget that the digital process is also a 100% positive improvement in other areas of imaging, where time is of the essence. for instance, making a critical diagnosis off of xrays.

just my 2 cents.

Steps to take DSLR photos that have the same magic as SLR:

1. Take photos digitally with same care and engagement as analog
2. Use the same lenses as on your SLR
3. Turn off all in camera post processing (no sharpening, no denoise, neutral/no picture profile, no styles, no auto white balance)
4. Use a DSLR that matches in quality the SLR filmstock (if you use top of the line filmstock, use a top of the line $10k DSLR)
5. Shoot raw
6. develop your digital pictures carefully

The description of the development process in the beginning of the video is not 100% accurate. The latent image already consists of actual silver metal, but is extremely weak. The developer amplifies the silver of the latent image and there is a whole range of different developer types which work in different ways to grow the metallic silver in a controlled fashion. You can even manipulate the way your developer will work by changing parameters like temperature, dilution, time etc. ... Having said that, you can even create images without using a developing agent at all by simply exposing the film for a very long period of time. Some very interesting photographs have been taken that way. :)

Prosumer digital cameras became to match film around 2007. Today even a basic entry model surpasses most analogue 35 mm cameras. For me this process of "analogue" makes sense only if the print is made through the analogue process. No scanning, no digital technology involved. If you want to view your image on monitor, which itself gets the signal from a digital source, you might as well make the whole process digital.

Shooting film and viewing the results on monitors, most of which are not calibrated at all, kind of misses the point. Wherease if you have a real physical piece of photographic paper with a "print" on it, you have a physical piece of matter that came to be by fully analogue technique, without any digital steps involved. The "print" might look different based on the specific lightning contidions when you look at it, but "prints" made using the analogue process with identical settings yield identical physical photographs.

I shot hundreds of film rolls. I did not want to go digital because of high cost and bad quality of early digital cameras. I was forced to go digital, when the last Photolab where they used a fully analogue process closed. I had to send my rolls to another Photolab which used a digital process, much like shown in this video. The developed the film, scanned it and then printed copies. It was afwul! The colors changed, contrast was artificially blowed up with loss of details in the highlight and shadows. On a 10 x 15 cm print I was able to see individual pixels without any magnifying tools. The old system was an Agfa machine, the new one was Fuji, maybe exactly the same machines as seen in this video.

For this reason, I went digital, my first DSLR being the EOS 30D. It took me pretty long to adapt to the smaller APS-C format, as I was used to full frame from my Praktica VLC3. The last time I shot a film was 6. 5. 2019. I shot on BW film which I can develop myself. I see little sense in doing color, as it requires outside facilities that use digital technologies anyway, to get "prints".

It remains extremly time consuming, doing all the things from taking a picture to getting a "print" by an analogue process. I do not want to mess with color chemistry at home. And I do not have a color head for the magnifier anyway.

Shooting on film, just to have it developed and scanned into a digital picutre is kind of only half-way there, if you really want to get the feeling of an authentic 100% analogue picture that you have on a piece of paper.

Film photos has HDR from the get go, the gamma/luminance level might be shaped like an S-curve. A digital photos in the other hand don't have HDR natively ("HDR" is added thru software later) and has its level in a linear/straight-line and even saturate too early in bright scene, but the curve can be reproduced in post-production and the missing detail (the saturated scene) can be fixed by taking multiple image with different exposure value and recover the missing data.

Hi all, I worked in the photofinishing industry for around 15 years (Fujifilm processing to be specific) and ran a Fuji Frontier mini lab, the same exact machine they are using but, instead of scanning to a file, the scans went to a photo processor that then projected the image onto actual photo paper (NOT photo quality, we had to load the paper in a dark room because it was light sensitive, the same paper you would use to print negatives directly to the paper). The one difference between film and digital that you touched on but didn't actually talk about is that with film you had a limited number of images to use. You could not take 20 or 30 pictures of the same subject and then delete the bad ones. this made you think about the shot before you tripped the shudder. Composition, lighting, exposer and the overall look (presence, atmosphere, feel, this piece has a lot of different descriptions) became more important because, many times, there was no chance to re-take the picture. imagine a trip to the Bahamas, if that picture wasn't quite right, what was the likelihood that you could go back and try again? As a pro photographer, this was one of the reasons I disliked shooting weddings. Digital photography leads to paying less attention to this kind of detail, if it's not right, just try again. It also leads to far less disappointment as you know you have the shot before you move on. I think that this is part of the different experience you get from film, the anticipation and either thrill of seeing the perfect picture once it's developed, or disappointment and conscious trouble shooting to figure out why it's not what you wanted, and what to do to not have that problem on the next roll.
Sorry, this is a longer post than I meant, but as I have been a photographer for around 50 (okay, I did the math and I got my first camera 43 years ago) and lived through the digital revolution, I guess I have an opinion or two (as well as being an "old coot" "get off my lawn ya whipper-snapper")
Anyway, Loved this video (love them all, this one just made me very nostalgic). Thanks again Dustin.

UGH, and that trumpet player, that is a gorgeous shot. There's this juxtaposition of joy and melancholy because everything is all a little gray, even the trumpet player wears some muted tones, there's people around to listen to him, but they aren't very actively engaging with him, and yet he still plays because he loves making music, it brings him joy. Beautiful.
The image of the statue of Blind Justice, like, technically not all too in the rule of thirds, but you can then interpenetrate that she is in the center of the world around and reflected on her and she keeps it balanced.
The street corner where you got the whole building and both vanishing points far to the left and on the right, what a trippy looking image, it's unnatural, but that's something photography can absolutely do because it only has the one eye, that's all it knows. I'm old enough that the only option I had when taking pictures was film. I don't have the artistic eye for appreciating film vs. digital quality, but I remember only having 24 or 36 pictures to take at a time. Every picture was special because you had to decide if it was worth that spot on your film, and you had to weigh it against future photo ops that may or may not happen. Not only that, but each picture had a cost associated to it. The cost of the film and the cost of development.

It's not like you really thought about it, but more like it was a general thing going on in the back of your head. And that general thing made each picture special.

There's also the anticipation. With digital you see the picture right away. With film you had to wait to get them back before you would know if you made the right decisions and took good pictures.

I look back on it fondly, but I don't miss it.

I have exposed a boatload of film in my day, but I for one will stick with digital. Main reason: never underestimate the value of taking more images and throwing away almost all of them!

Some Music Historians have suggested that Debussy’s music is great, not so much that he knew how to write great music, but that he knew how to throw away or revise the music he wrote that wasn’t good enough.

In nature photography or portraiture especially, there are always lots of considerations in the composition of an image that you can’t control: A gust of wind slightly moves the subject, slight camera movements with your heartbeats (in hand-held shots), etc. Most of these subtle quirks are much easier to see as you review the photos you take, and much harder “in the heat of the moment,” while you’re capturing the image.

So, go digital, take oodles of photos, and throw virtually all of them away!

I was a photography student here in the UK in the early 80s. We used to process C41 colour film by hand in a darkroom. The whole developing process took about 30 minutes, with the first 15 minutes or so in complete darkness. The lights could be on for the later processes. In order to maintain consistency during darkness, we used a cassette tape recorder, which would instruct us when to lower the film into each bath, and when to agitate the film in the mixture. There were a number of problems. If the film was agitated too much it would result in over-exposed negatives, which could be ascertained through the use of test strips. Too little agitation resulted in under-exposure. Also, over time the cassette tape became less accurate as the tape stretched through extensive use.

There were no scanners, so we’d have to make “contact sheets” (literally bringing the negatives into contact with photo paper), in order to see the results.

Pure nostalgia. Beside of process, it doesn't make sense to shoot analog nowadays. You can simulate analog look by digital processing and I don't mean simple filters. So if you want just that analog look, it is easier (and cheaper) to shoot digital and then edit raw files. With adapting vintage lenses and software like Nik Collection, RNI, VSCO (complex profiles for LRC)... you cannot find difference at the and of the process.

This video hits home with me. When I was growing up all through my young life I can recall this dark and somewhat mysterious room in our basement called "The Darkroom" it was filled with all sorts of mechanical things and tubs and sinks and the most unique set smells. It seemed truly magical that one day my Dad was out with us taking photos or home movies and just days or even hours later there they would all be on proof sheets. Mom and Dad and every so often the kiddos would choose the best ones. Off he would go and a few snacks and play time later, Boom, there they were all still holding the magical smells and the warmth on the print dryer still clinging to the prints. Dad had all sorts of different papers that had all sorts of different textures and different glosses from supper shiny to the really flat and some with a deep texture to them. Those papers we were really careful with because of the price. As I grew I started becoming more interested and would join him and got to understand much more of the process. One of my favorite parts was working with the "Inlarger". You could be a part of bringing a photo to life. I learned how to time the image and how to correct for some mistakes by shadowing with all sorts of tools and even how to hold the negative at angles to change the focal plane of the print to enhance and certain qualities of the photo. Then off to watch the development of the photo itself. Watch the image start to form almost out of no where. It was wonderful to watch. Dad had 14 cameras and a huge selection of lens options to go with them. He would take time to explain what each did and oversee as I grew to have some experience. I can still remember the summer I ask if I could take a camera and use it for a project. He ask about the project and why I wanted a certain camera to accomplish a look I was after. After what seemed like a two hour discussion, he said sure son use what you like. It wasn't until much later in life did I understand the smile on his face. I guess after countless hours of training and working with different cameras and tools in printing we ended up at the one point it time when he knew I understood, not only the value of the camera in my hand, but also the techniques I had in mind to provided a certain result. I guess it was a point of passage for he and I. He was proud to see one of his sons first real accomplishments. I come from a family of 6 kids. My father was a Architect. He had a Doctorate in Architecture and Masteres in Mechanical engineering. He was a pretty smart fella. I still have that old enlarger and a few of the more collectible cameras he had in his collection.
So Thank You! Watching your video brought back so many memories for me.

Honestly, one of the things that is missing from today's film revival is the art of optical printing. Using an enlarger to make physical prints of the negatives on emulsion paper. Too many film negatives are simply scanned and stored or at best printed by computer. There is an entire missing step to this art that makes the print something much more special that a print that comes from an inkjet printer.
Its a process that has been automated for years with mini-lab machines, but which benefits greatly from individual attention to the printing process. In either case, an automated print or a hand crafted print, the feel is entirely different from a computer generated print on a computer driven printer. Especially if you are the one focusing the negative, exposing and developing the paper and then holding a truly physical representation of a moment.

Okay, this will be long comment.

Film is not coming back. It's a niche.
I'm at my 30s, and I grew up in Russia, so, believe me, I had all the analogue stuff. Vinyls, black-and-white tv, tapes, video taped, and of course film cameras.

I don’t feel it. Really I don’t. I can see how excited and passionate Destin is. I know few people with that "film feeling" but I personally don’t get it. I see all this film stuff as unnecessary complications and this IS what it is now. You have limited amount of shots, you’re limited with same ISO, you have way fewer things done automatically for you. And after that you need to get to the lab, process it and then see result. I find it frustrating. Digital is great! It makes you to be determined on the process itself, not thinking about all this stuff surrounding film process.

I’m all digital. I read my books on screen since I got my first e-Ink reader. And I shoot digitally since I got my first digital camera. I listen to my music digitally. I communicate with people digitally. I think the digital world is underestimated in our days. Because we have everything digitalized. But try to deconstruct it. Try to see the whole process that the digital camera does to capture the light and make it a picture on the screen. I can assure you the process of encoding things into digital representation is fascinating. It is the miracle of technology. I can’t even imagine the way of thinking of the pioneers of the digital era who created the ways for us to casually take our phone from the pocket make a high definition video and send it right away to the other side of the world in seconds. We become too familiar with it too quickly. We didn’t have this tech just 20-30 years ago!

Now back to film. When it comes to creation process, I’m a simple man. Whatever helps you to create better art is good for you. If you’re getting in this mood of creation euphoria with film, then use film. If you’re a writer and you get your creation mood sitting naked in the attic and typing your novel on 1941 Underwood type-writer, that’s great!
But film itself doesn’t make good photography. Grain doesn’t make good photography. It’s you. You make good photography. Your vision is the most important part of the process. So never forget to put your soul in what you’re doing. No matter the methods and ways of creation process.

Best of luck for everyone who’s got to this part.

My Dad was a professional photographer, with his own darkroom. This was in the days before digital scanning, so Dad had to work from the bare negatives, figuring out what he was looking at, and how best to frame it for printing. With color photos, it got even more complex, adjusting the color with gradient gelatin filters in the print head. Sometimes he would let me come down and help develop film in the canisters like you showed in the beginning. You brought back a lot of memories for me; he truly was an artist. BTW, that revolving dark door at the lab, they had one of those at the photography supply business where Dad got his chemicals. I had lots of fun going inside and pretending to disappear!

There's a few things to point out though. The vast majority of people when there was no digital cameras around were only using point and shoot cameras. Those don't give you the luxury of composing the shot you want the same way an SLR does. You don't have the lenses, there's no depth of field adjustment and as such the photos I took up until the day I got my own (digital) SLR were nothing to be particularly proud of.

Then there's the one thing which I find very important that digital does really well but which you can't get from analog and that's timestamps. There are cameras which will incorporate a timestamp on your shot and that can be helpful if you don't mind it on your photos but other than that, there's no way to know exactly when a photo has been taken unless you took a record in a notebook or something of the time and date and location. This may seem trifle, especially if the image is meant to be a work of art, but for memories it means that very often old photos will lack a temporal reference as you struggle to recall when a shot was taken and at what time.

I'm pretty sure I still have a point and shoot from 2006 that is only half used and should probably be finished up so I can develop the roll one last time. Having done my own development once in black and white I can say with confidence that this is one thing that gave me the photography bug but while I see what you're saying about how much warmer and "authentic" film looks like, I still prefer digital. Not because it gives me the luxury of taking lots of throwaway images because I'm quite frugal with my shots unless I try to shoot things in motion but because I always take the time to compose my shots, even with my smartphone and its lower quality sensor... but then again I do come from the film age of photography so when you learnt to shoot this way, it stays with you I suppose.

I haven't shot film since the early 2000's, but in the early and mid 90's I was a formally trained photographer in the Marines, and watching this brought back a lot of really cool memories.  I spent a lot of time doing B&W darkroom work, and color as well, and those chemicals can be really nasty.  Also we didn't have to pop the ends off of the film canisters to get the film out, we had a little clip that we could use to fish the leader out and the canisters were recycled.  Our training was at Lowry AFB in Denver (now closed), and you couldn't ask for a better place to learn photography.  Right before I got out in 1994 I saw the beginnings of digital.  You would attach a special back to a film camera that had a sensor in it, and a cable connected it to a hard drive you clipped to your belt that was probably similar in size to a VHS tape, and it held anywhere from 50-150 images.

So, hopefully I can add something here. The nitrogen isn't pumped in because oxygen hurts the chemistry (oxygen does hurt the chemistry). It's pumped in because it agitates the chemistry. As the film develops, the chemicals near the film and directly in contact with it become used up and exhausted. The nitrogen bubbles move the chemistry around in the tank and bring fresh chemistry in contact with the film. The reason they use nitrogen for this instead of air is that air would oxidize the chemicals. When you develop film by hand you follow a specific agitation schedule, you will either turn the whole tank upside down and back right again, or use a little rod to spin the film reels in the tank. Film chemistry (especially color chemistry) is sensitive to temperature, time and agitation so it's extremely important to be consistent with those variables if you want consistent results.

It’s simply just more entertaining to watch a man experience true passion. Another great example is the pecan video. Another one of my favorites, and the farmer that taught us everything in the video is just a simple man, living in an instance of passion every moment he spends working.

Wow, I had no idea this was still possible. I learned my photography on film. Started with a 120 box camera and then picked up 35mm while in the Navy during the 1970s. I never did use a lab for digital scanning. Always prints and then I went to positive slide film, still have my Kodak carousel projector. Loved shooting kodachrome and ektachrome. You could buy 200 asa and push it to 400 asa or 800 asa. Or, you could go the other way to very slow film, less than 100 asa, and get very fine grain along with great color (tripod required).

I always was a bit frustrated by the wait. First to finish a 36 exposure roll in the camera and then wait for the developer. Because of this and the expense, I learned to make every shot count; composition, light, everything. I kept a notebook of my shots, lighting, subject, settings, etc. My normal day job was as an electronic technician, then engineer. Back in those days everyone I knew had set up their own dark room and processed their own film. It teaches you everything you talked about in this video and I feel a bit surprised that this knowledge has been nearly lost by the general public.

I think the reason film photography is so good is because of the care and effort involved, and still today even with a digital camera, I try to make every shot count. Even so, digital photography still looks a bit flat footed to me and often the energy is not there. I know there's a place and time for point and shoot, and I think I've lost some of the passion I had shooting with film. Thanks for an inspiring video.

Hey Destin if you want to come out to Pennsylvania I could show you one of these rack-dipping systems like this but it's the size of a building :D No exaggeration, my father single-handedly designed and then BUILT a huge rack-dipping system for an electro-coating business. It functions exactly like this one but it's about the size of a large house. I know very well that "film feeling"...
I had my first darkroom back in 1969 (I was 11 at the time) and constantly fighting with my parents imploring me to get in the garden and play under the sun instead of a faint yellow-greenish safety lamp (and finally release the sitting room that I was commandeering for my purposes)
I fondly remember the smell of the film, of the developing and fixing bath, the magical atmosphere and the thrilling expectation watching at the slowly forming image on photo paper to check if there were some good shots amongst those carefully distilled and planned in a mere 36-frame strip, that was all my weekly pocket money could allow.
I had plenty of free time, energy and curiosity then. Nowadays the frantic lifestyle sadly prevents me from merely thinking about setting up a darkroom again. A digital camera has long since replaced my glorious, epoch-making Nikon F, but the true pleasure of photographing is hopelessly lost.
And every time I have to reluctantly take a smartphone shot, my stomach is churning and I can't but think to Pink Floyd's verses:
"When I was a child
I caught a fleeting glimpse
Out of the corner of my eye
I turned to look but it was gone

Much like vinyl, the "feel" of film photography comes from imperfection. Human eyes do not see perfectly, our brains are hardwired to focus on colors like green (because we evolved to live among green plants) and tan/orange/red (because those are our skin tones) and the chemistry required for film to work properly was designed in such a way that it prioritizes those colors. So when we get film prints or scans back, they look magically "natural" and organic because they're closer to the color toning we relate to in the beauty we see in the world. With vinyl, the "warmth" people ascribe to the sound compared to digital is present because of harmonics, the same harmonics our ears pick up on and our brains subconsciously detect, and it feels good. Digital reproduces everything consistently, and over time we get used to that consistency, but when we compare it to analog images or sound, we can instantly tell that the analog versions retain the imperfections our brains are naturally inclined to focus on. This is why film/vinyl enthusiasts often refer to the digital counterparts of recorded audio/video as "sterile" or less interesting, because it doesn't recreate the imperfections that coincide with the biases our brains are naturally inclined to focus on. It's natural, organic, genetic magic :)

We had a dark room at our high school in the mid 90's and let me tell ya the things that happened in that dark room would make Larry Flint Blush.

But the one thing I remember seeing in there was a very nicely made, hand painted sign, that said
"Give me Kodachrome or give me death."
Seeing as I wasn't one of the photography students I didn't understand the significance of it.
That was until I asked the teacher about it, amazing older guy with tons of knowledge to share BTW. When I inquired about the sign, he immediately replied by asking me essentially "do you want the quick easy version or the long version that involves a few hours of your time," I basically said, "that's a pretty definite statement in there, I'll take the long version".

The long version turned out to be a 5 page paper explaining why Kodachrome was the pinnacle of man's image capturing achievements. For doing so you would learn the significance of the sign, BUT you were also awarded 100 extra credit point redeemable to ANY of the teachers in the Industrial Art Dept.. Also included was an invitation to his annual "kodachrome show" for the photography students to view his collection of kodachrome photographs he done as well as others he's bought, was given, etc, there were some absolutely stunning photos in his collection.

Overall it was interesting, and found that the sign was done "tongue in cheek" as a gift from one of his friends teasing him about his fascination with kodachrome film, and I was told Kpdachrome always make the world look better". Definitely one of those lessons that you remember lol.

As someone who grew up and learned to shoot on film and then became a professional working with DSLRs, I understand the appeal to going back. It's not just the nostalgia (though that plays a majority of it, at least for me), but the mechanical feedback as well as the analogue control over exposure factors. I don't know if those make every photographer better, but they certainly helped me grasp a better understanding of the basics of photography when I first handled a camera in my preteens and, thusly, made me a better photographer today.

I love the walk down memory lane and it's a trip to be in a C-41 and line. The photography school did the E-6 processing with the dip dunk, and for our black and white, we had the Versamat from Kodak. We sore of used that for our quick and dirty, but preferred the handline for that as well.

For me, having paid 20 grand for a medium format camera system as I did nature photography, I was constantly dealing with the minimums such as focal distance, depth of field and light. Made getting great shots hard, and with my desire for National Geographic quality photography for articles, with wasn't hard to reach a $4,500 color lab bill.

What blew me away is that even with a very basic digital SLR, a camera body and wide to normal telephoto zoom lens, and a telephoto zoom lens, way out performs that big film camera system for about $1,500. I haven't done much lab work, but am great at photoshop and the power available to both trained and average photographers is totally amazing. There are way to create a film look to digital as well.

I worked in labs like this for 22 years. We printed everything though. A machine made the little 4x6 pics and anything bigger we did in the darkroom by hand. It looks like they don't process slide film in the E6 process. You can "cross process" film also, by sending slide film (which has a reversal chemical that makes it positive) through the C41 chemistry and the colors come out totally random and negative and has no red control layer so is a bit tricky to print. You use a piece of unexposed C41 film sandwiched with it.

The great thing about film is the personal investment and the, well, risk. I recall shooting my cousin’s wedding as an amateur (circa 1997) in 35mm because we were poor and she knew I had at least some experience with photography. Pros would laugh, but I was nervous beyond belief. I rented equipment, bought the best film we could afford (Ektar 125 I think), and took a stupid number of test shots. And on the actual day I had to plan out which shots she needed vs how many exposures I had. The pics turned out fine. But that’s film. It costs much more. Time, planning, risk, angst. Investment. That’s why film photography feels different.

Also… Yes! The smell of the dark room! I took two years of photography in HS in 1988-90 (and I had my own b&w dark room later) and it’s some of my best memories. Good old Kodak D-76 developer! And the tangy smell of the acetic acid stop bath… the ammonium thiosulfate fixer. The dim red lights of the print room and the complete pitch darkness of the tank room. And it’s true - you learn to work with all your other senses (Or you don’t and you wreck your film.) Then you check your negatives in the light and you know whether you got good contrast or not. Then you go to the printers and the magic of your work shows up on the photo paper right before your eyes. Maybe you go back and adjust the print exposure and reprint. And color printing was real art… adjusting the brightness, exposure time, cyan, magenta and yellow just right? Shheeeesh! I learned about composition and what makes for good contrasty and interesting images. It can be an enjoyable craft.

I’m a NDT (Non-Destructive Testing) Technician’s Assistant, just started a few weeks ago, and we do a lot of different types of testing but the main thing we do is “X-Ray” welds. Everyone refers to it as “X-Ray” but is is really Gamma Rays from a Ir-192 source and we use all film. If you haven’t seen it you got to look it up. It was crazy to me when I first found out that even today film is still used.

The most enjoyable class I took in college was photography. We had to go out an shoot lots of black and white film and then come back into the lab and develop it.  We learned the whole process, from removing the film from the cassette to making the final print. This was in the early 70's, so scanning the developed film wasn't part of the process. Instead, after developing the film we went into the darkroom and exposed the image onto Kodak paper. Then the paper went through chemical baths, the details of which I don't remember, to produce the final positive image from the negative. It was like magic! And totally enjoyable. We invested many many hours for the few college credits we got, but it was totally worth it.

I understand the qualities that draw people to old technologies like this. I may not be able to see the warmth that film adds, but I can hear the warmth an acoustic piano adds over a digital one and I imagine it's similar with film vs. digital. That being said, They are still archaic technologies that don't fit into our modern life. I can't help but think that at some point people are going to start trying to get the same qualities with digital methodologies and advance current technologies rather than rely on the past and stagnate innovation.

It's the same with electric cars. One complaint I hear of electric cars from car people is that the don't have the growls that combustion cars do. I totally get that. And that's why the likes of BWM are starting to hire composers like Hans Zimmer to create new sounds for electric cars. Right now, they're just being pumped out through speakers, but I could see in the not too distant future some of those added sounds being created mechanically in components and systems that serve no other purpose than to make the vehicle sound nice.

I challenge you to scientifically test your hypothesis that there's something very different about the quality of film by having someone else randomize a set of photos that include many equally beautiful and evocative digital and film based photos. See if you really do have some very significant ability to tell a difference or if you are just projecting your expectation beforehand onto the experience.

I'm betting you're going to find the mystical feeling to be generated by your own internal mechanisms, but I hope that doesn't diminish the experience for you and instead highlights the power of self-actualization and personal responsibility in our experience of the world.

It can be empowering to know that you can feel the beauty and majesty of nature, or the warmth of seeing a family care for one another, even when you could have also reduced it down to just hydrological process shaping the landscape, or maximization of genetic viability that causes a mother's love. You have a choice to have both views work together, or one to dominate over the other.

As we explore the truth of life we must not diminish the truth of the experience of living. (...and that's why I love your channel. The wonder is beautiful!)

This video couldn't be more perfectly timed. While digging through some old boxes this weekend, I found a 35mm camera I had long forgotten about, and inside it...an undeveloped roll of film. Now I know where to send it!

When I was in my mid to late twenties (late '00's) I worked at a drugstore that did photo development. When I worked there we had a machine that was roughly the size of two water cooler machines put together, that developed the negative.

Then you would feed the developed negative into a machine that was roughly the size of a copier that you'd find in a office; which actually let you process, make any requested alterations, and develop the pictures.

We also had a digital photo kiosk that I had to learn by myself through trial and error, twice (we switch from being a Kodak shop to being a Fuji one and the Fuji photo development, both film and digital was different enough that if you missed training day it was a little irritating trying to figure it out).

Destin, you're only a few years younger than me (I'm 43 in a few months) so i feel like you should already be more well versed in film than digital. I grew up with film. I started out with crappy 110 cameras and eventually my Dad gave me his Olypus OM-10 35mm SLR. I played around with filters and double exposures and all manner of trickery. This was LONG before I knew about Photoshop. I didn't buy my first DSLR until just a few years ago. I find it funny that you talk about having a limited number of photos to take because not only was that what I learned on, I sometimes still (try) to limit myself to 24 or 36 images just to stay sharp.

All that being said, the ability to continue shooting without having to either switch cameras or potentially miss a shot while changing rolls along with being able to shoot video all in one camera is something 20 year old me would have believed impossible. And now with mirrorless taking the industry as well as nearly everyone having high resolution still and video cameras right in their pocket... what can you say but technology is amazing!

Man, you’re taking me back to college at the cusp of the 80s/90s and trying to wind my black and white film onto steel film reels so they can be put into a light tight development jar. The one you showed at the start of the video was a plastic mechanical one that would just ratchet it in automatically for you. But the stainless steel ones took a lot of abuse and lasted a long time. However, they sure did take practice to load right without any kinks and such. And then you had to do it in total blackness. It was the most finicky part of darkroom photography. On top of that, temperature is really important when developing. Where I was in school, the summers were HOT and the cold water pipes were not insulated. So sometimes the developers and rinses were simply not the right temperature (too warm), there was nothing you could do about it, and you had to adjust your chemical and rinse times on the fly. Sometimes you ended up with film that came out fine, sometimes it was off but created some wonderful pre-digital effects, and sometimes the whole role was made into garbage. I escaped ever having a roll destroyed, but I saw plenty of commiseration happening in the common areas of the darkroom when people lost their work on those rolls.

On one hand, I do get the value in using primitive methods. "Primitive" is not a pejorative, the whole benefit here is in the lower quality output and the difficulty and unreliability of the process. It's like going camping when you have a perfectly good house, or unskilled hand crafting of things you could just buy at Walmart. There's a certain increased personal value to something you did the hard way, and that isn't perfect because it wasn't meant to be.

But personally, I really love digital. My mindset of photography was set in the film era and even now it's such a freeing feeling not to have to stress over every shot, not to have to wait and hope that it turns out ok, not to have important things lost because those few frames I had messed up and I didn't find out for weeks until I finished the roll... there's no way I would even consider taking up film again. I also like the crispness of digital photographs over the textural "warmth" of film photos. I don't print much, but in my office I'm surrounded by nature photos I took with digital that I'd never have taken with film because I'd be afraid of "wasting" it and because the immediate feedback allowed me to dial in on how to take the photos.

I started with a 110 camera Dad gave me, used pinhole cameras for school and other projects, and on rare occasions used Dad's SLR he bought in the 70s, and even developed black and white film myself, and I definitely don't regret having done so, but to me, digital was such a transformative, freeing experience that turned photography from that activity I did with Dad because he liked it, to something I actually could use and enjoy.

I took a photography class back in college circa 2005 or so. We shot black and white film, had to do our own developing, AND had to develop our own prints on photo paper. I loved every second of it. Learning how to pull and push the film during development, being able to make a contact sheet then change the result on the photo paper when you used the enlargers. I really enjoyed using those enlargers, making adjustments to the aperture and timings then manually burning or shading out different sections of the scene to compensate for under exposures or over exposures on the film. Then using contrast filters... man, this brought me back lol

Truly epic... just wish the cost of all the things were less or I'd still do it. I use digital now. Since I learned on film I've always been more careful with my shots... I rarely use the spray and pray approach... even with action shots. I also have given myself challenges to only take x number of shots in an outing: it forces you to take your time and compose.

Something I learned is that the prints from color film in the 90's on where digital prints and not an additional exposure and chemical process.

All the prints I did because in school were done by projecting light through the film negative on to photosensitive paper, then developing. This whole process could be done in a dark room lit by red light that the paper was not sensitive to.

I had assumed (mostly by the question having never occurred to me till now) that commercial photo prints were done similarly. But it makes more sense to have been using ink printing processes for cost, speed and color.

It took me quite awhile to transition from film to digital. I really was resistant to it. I bought my first serious film camera in 1970. It was a square format medium format camera. I quickly moved to 35mm and stayed with that format for the next 40 years. Mastery is a lot different with film. Color film whether negative or positive (slide) has less exposure latitude than your brain does when interpreting what your eye sees. And of course monotone (B&W) is a completely different animal. Of course my generation grew up with monochrome TV and it was a lot more familiar than more recent generations. I am glad that film has come back into favor, perhaps we will again appreciate the cameras art of the masters that were taking images from the pre digital period. And many of the books out there exploring the art will come back in favor as well.

@SmarterEveryDay -  You keep saying that there is something "magical" about film that just looks better than digital.  This channel is all about investigating those hidden details.  You showed how film gets processed, but never address the "magic" of film.  So here is my challenge to you:  Build a mirror rig with splitter lenses that will allow both a digital camera and a film camera to see the same scene from the same angle and take some pictures with both using a variety of lighting and targets.  Get the digitals of the film back and show a side by side comparison.  Next, take the image pairs to a specialist in training AI neural networks to create a custom image filter that can input a digital image, and output a digitized film image, and see if you can recreate the same looks and feel of film from a digital camera.  Both image sets are just pixels on the screen with the same LCD monitor color palette.  The only difference is the source pixels from the two cameras, and an AI neural net can probably do a pretty good job of converting the color space from one to the other.

I guess what I’m missing is that at the end of the day, you are still ending up with a digital file.  What we are gaining here is an intermediate step.  The quality of the end digital file is only as good as the scanner and the technician doing the color correction.  I want to see a comparison between a truly developed and transferred image to paper vs a printed digital image.

This video was especially interesting to me. I ran one-hour photo labs for drugstores for a decade, ending right as the transition from film to digital was beyond the tipping point. We used Noritsu and Fuji machines roughly the size of a large kitchen island. Because we didn't have a darkroom, the machines were the darkrooms.

For the film, we'd draw out the end, slice off the tongue, and tape it to a plastic card inserted into the machine. We applied twin check stickers, like Indie does, to ensure that negatives could be traced to the correct order envelope. When the card was inserted into the machine and the door was sealed, the machine drew the card and the attached film through the chemistry on a serpentine track. The machine would detect the end of the roll and cut the negatives free from their container, dropping the empties into a bin. At the other end of the machine, the negatives came out as a single strip.

We'd take the processed negatives to the printer and thread them into a track. The negatives were drawn through frame by frame. We could adjust the color balance and lightness/darkness of each frame separately. Earlier machines projected light through the negatives directly onto the photosensitive paper inside the machine, which would then be drawn on another serpentine track through the chemistry, a rinse, and a dryer to be deposited on a conveyer belt at the top of the machine. Later machines digitally scanned the negatives and projected the scanned image onto the paper before sending it through the process. These machines also handled files from digital media, and by around 2006 or so were connected to the internet to receive customer orders online. Different sized photos required different widths of paper, so we often traded out light-sealed paper cartridges to print 4x6s, 5x7s, and 8x10s.

(EDIT: I submitted this before getting to the scanner section. That GUI is exactly what I used in the early- to mid-naughties on my Noritsu and Fuji machines!)

Finally, we'd hand-cut the negatives and tuck them into the plastic accordion sleeves us middle-aged folks grew up seeing. Negatives and photos went into the envelope, and then the order would lie waiting for several days while the customer who was adamant that they needed the photos right away forgot that they'd even dropped them off. :P

I started doing film photography after getting a SLR that also fit my Canon EF lenses for my DSLR. As a Millennial (I graduated high school in 2002), I was one of the last Millennials whom had used a disposable film camera on field trips and one of the first to get a digital camera. My high school graduation gift from my dad was a 1.3 megapixel digital point and shoot camera. After cutting my teeth with a Canon Rebel XS in 2011, I decided to try my luck again with film. Things went well. I would take the film canister, drop it off at Walmart, and the photo lab tech would send it off to Fuji Film for development. One day I only got half of the scanned prints back, with weird effects on the prints. No answer as to what happened, whether it was the camera, or the film. So I started to develop my own color film at home with a light tight canister. I came to the conclusion that it was the film, as I had no negatives come back from Fuji Film (they just trashed the negatives) and could not reproduce the weird effects with the camera.

I decided to develop my dad's old rolls of film. I knew that I could see something on the negatives, but when I scanned the negatives in, everything looked white. I figured Fuji Film would of just thrown the rolls away and be like, "Sorry!" Well, I decided to use Photoshop CS3, my new "digital darkroom" to try and salvage the images. I managed to salvage over 243 images. What came to light really surprised me, and I was able to date the film. My sister was only one pound some ounces when she was born premature. They had to put her in baby doll clothes she was so little. So I have seen the photos of my sister in the NICU, and photos of her at home a year or more later. These photos contained the transition from when my sister first came home from the hospital after being born. It wasn't the best in the world, being 30 years old and not being developed in many years. However, it was still enough to be recognizable. I gave the prints that I made from the negatives to my sister for her 30th birthday in 2016. She then ruined it by asking, "How come nobody's ever seen these photos before?!"

I'd be very interested in a follow-up detailing how prints were made before the digital revolution. It all seemed like magic. I sent in a roll of plastic and got back beautiful pictures and no computers were involved. Clearly it's some kind of process involving light and chemicals but I'd love to see the details through your eyes.

I have a very old 1950s era Nikon camera that I inherited from my grandfather who was at one time (in the 70s I believe) president of the Men's Garden Club of America. His photographs are amazing, and I love the camera. A couple of years ago, I bought a newer Nikon D3400 (Yes, it's not the top of the line) for the North American Eclipse. I chose to buy a Nikon over a Canon or other brand because I wanted to use my grandfather's old lenses in the new camera. I think the old lenses are <i>part</i> of the reason film photos have that nostalgic feel. When I clip in my non-smart, antique lenses into my DSLR, I DO get the same feelings out of the pictures. I agree that the chemistry of film and developing process adds a lot to the "feel" of film photos, but the smart lenses of today's cameras are, IMHO, too smart. My old manual focus lenses in the body of a modern CCD camera still require the skill to frame and focus your shot, and the pictures are a lot better because of it.

I dreamed that Kodak decided to bring back Kodachrome.  The only true archival color film  that became commercially available to public in the late 1930's, and blossomed from the 50's through 90's.  Kodachrome is a positive transparency film unlike its color negative c41 films, but silver halide nonetheless, even though pre processing it's actually black and white.  I have Kodachrome 25 and 64 slides taken in the 70s and today are just as vibrant after being stored properly in the dark.

One of the most mind blowing things about traditional photography is that we would never have been able to invent digital photography, or any of our advanced integrated circuitry without it. Digital camera sensors are made by pretty much the same process as film development!

IT all depends on the film and the process


Like the Magic that Takes place on the K14 process for Kodachrome, which starts its life as a black & white film and becomes a color film. It's longevity is the lack of organic couplers, which is the reason old color photos turn red, when those organic couplers decay or decompose!!

You want to talk film and processing, hit me up, one of my degrees from Brooks Institute in 1985, was Color Technology, or Photo Lab Management, something that has somewhat become obsolete!! .

Look for scanners that use ICE to keep the dust and hairs out of the scan.  Not sure you can even find ICE anymore.  Amazing technology.  It does not manipulate the scan data. It uses a different wavelength to scan the front and back of the film and does a comparison to phase out the dust/hair.  The scan pixels are not changed.

Thanks for creating this video. I grew up in Rochester, NY (the home of Kodak). My father worked there during the heyday of film (60's-90's) so most of my childhood memories revolve around photography. There is something magical about taking pictures using a film camera. One of my favorite parts was being able to experience the situation all over again when you received your prints.
