Interesting. I worked at a photo lab for a couple of years, and we had these massive Fuji machines that did everything for you. We didn't even need a dark room - we had dark BOXES, for doing certain tasks (loading rolls of photo paper into these massive canisters that mated into the printing machine, and also for extracting non-35 mm film), but that was it. Also, we had a neat little device for extracting the leader of the film from the canister...it was like, a roll of thick tape, sticky on one side, non-sticky on the other, mounted into a desktop device that allowed you to easily advance and retrieve the tape. You'd stick the end of the tape into the slit that the film comes out of, and fish around in there, and the tape would stick to the leader and you could extract it. Then, you would cut the leader, use the double-sticker system to label the film and the envelop from whence it came (so that it was always paired with the right person's information), tape (on both sides) the film to this plastic leader sheet, which got fed into the machine, and it would pull the film out of the canister as it advanced, meaning that it was never exposed to the light. Each leader sheet could do two rolls of film. After about 8 minutes, the film would be developed.

I also have some experience with the B+W home darkroom method, which is done completely in the dark (for the film development process). I was in photo club at school as a teen, so I learned the entire black and white technique, and still have a lot of photos from that period of my life. Also...darkrooms are great places for making out. Just sayin'. I met my first girlfriend in photo club, and we spent plenty of hours in the darkroom, not all of them working :).

DINFOS graduate here. 1984.
I first learned how to use a 35mm camera there at Ft. Ben Harris, IN.
We were told that the development labs we used in foto journalism class were prison cells from WWII. Pretty small rooms, but we only developed B&W film. There was a graveyard with German POWs buried there, so the prison cell idea is plausible. But I suspect the barracks we stayed in were the real POW housing.
DINFOS has since relocated. Ft. Ben is virtually gone. But the memories of the pictures I took with that 35mm camera are with me today.
Speaking of.. today I print a different kind of photo: Electronic circuitry on silicone at a microchip manufacturing company. Watching IC patterns develop in an instant looks like magic.
Digital pix are a dozen for a penny.
Film is forever.

For 100+ years this was the way it was done.  For those of us who grew up with analog film, we had to be selective about taking pictures.  Make sure that it was the moment to capture for 'posterity.'  After all there were only so many 'shots' on a roll for film.  I remember when my older brother got into photography.  My father had done some developing when he was younger, so my brother inherited a contact printer as well as an enlarger.  That was because 35mm is a little smaller than 1.5 inch.  In order to see the prints they had to be enlarged to be viewable.  Nearly 1/2 of one shelf the 1949 GE fridge was taken up with brown bottles of chemicals.  The process that was demonstrated here was for B&W.  For Color it  is more complicated.  They did not demonstrate the printing process.  Thus more chemicals.

Destin, with a set of night vision goggles on: "So what do you use this for"
Hannah: "To see"

The support (AKA the acetate "base") is a very light gray for negative films. This is an additional anti-halation measure. The gray dye provides what you might call a "dimensionally anisotropic" light-blocker. Light going through the film is only trivially mimimized, passing only through a microscopic layer of dye, but, light being piped through the support "sideways" passes through a lot of the dye.

When I did some film in school we had “red lights” is what we called them. We were able to have those lights on in the dark room and they had filters on them that allowed us to still see a little bit but not effect the film. Why couldn’t they do that?

It's been a long time since I last developed B&W, at school, and then again at university (spectroscopy, on glass plates). Good memories, but I'd say that I only truly learned how to get a good shot, including control of aperture and shutter speed once I went digital. For learning the feedback cycle is really long. That said, once you have that under control I can certainly see the magic (4 photons of a crystal to turn black).

Yeah, I grew up with film in the 70s and 80s, had my own darkroom, and I’ve shot goodness knows how many rolls of film, and I’ll NEVER go back.  There’s some argument for mid and large-format media having better resolution, but even that gap is closing fast.  Nostalgia is fun, but I’ve got projects to finish and other things to do rather than hassle with dealing with all the (all too variable) analog steps from exposure to print.  I loved it at the time, and the experience was invaluable as I got into layout and pre-press work, but we pressed hard to get to an all-digital workflow as soon as we could.

Back in the mid '70s I did a lot of work with B&W film for my college newspaper.  I shot photos, developed film, and made prints in a darkroom.  You can shoot ASA400 film at ASA1200 speeds and using a special developer increase the grain.  In printing you can dodge to decrease exposure of an area and burn to increase.  I was an apprentice verging on journeyman but loved it.  At least half of the art in film photography is in the printing.  It's also time intensive and requires special papers, chemicals, and equipment.  Developing is cookbook stuff.  After working with B&W film you exit the darkroom smelling like vinegar due to the acetic acid in the stop bath.
Whimper!  “An old machine from the 90’s”. Old?  1990’s? That Really makes the kids feel old.

I ran these Fuji machines at a Wal mart photo lab, back in the militiamen change era. It  was so cool to see then again! I took trips around the world and saw great moments in peoples lifes, before they did. It was an enjoyable job, to color correct people's memories.

I visited a German Art museum which did not allow photography.  I asked why and it was because flash photography damaged the paintings and paper,  I pointed out I was using a film camera which did not have a flash attachment, but used film meant for low light.  They allowed me in with the camera.

This make me so happy and so sad.
My family business was film processing and printing. I even put a few years into the business my self in the 90's & 00's in one of London's top professional photo labs.
But then I got to watch as my industry, IT, destroyed the business.
So much knowledge and experence were lost forever, in a very few short years. It was devastating.

I'm so glad that film is starting to make a come back. It's not just about the moment, there is also a quality and warmness to film images that no amount of filters have ever been able to replicate. OK, laughing all the way. As one that started developing their own film about 1972, give me digital any day. Chemical processing has so many variables that you pretty much eliminate or at least control much better. Also, waiting for weeks to see my pictures just drives me nuts. I gave my darkroom away years ago. I went digital and never looked back. My poor Nikon F (circa 1962) hasn't had a roll of film for at least 10 years. Still have it for old times sake, but don't use it.

As for quality, I prefer the digital manipulation possible in a digital darkroom. I have so much more control and more freedom, and mostly so much easier to make basic adjustments, so much easier to control contrast, give me digital any day. In photography I embrace progress (besides, scan negative to print is digital photography. Just skip the film and skip the processor)
